Meanwhile, the pirates who captured her children sold them and the nurse to Messer Guasparrino d'Oria in Genoa, who used them as slaves. The nurse, to protect the children, changed Giusfredi's name to Giannotto di Procida and taught him to conceal his identity. Giannotto, at sixteen, fled Genoa and became a soldier. After three or four years, hearing his father was alive but imprisoned, he despaired and took service with Currado Malespina. He often saw his mother, but neither recognized the other due to the changes wrought by time and hardship.

Currado's daughter, Spina, a young widow, fell in love with Giannotto, and they became lovers. Their indiscretion led to their discovery by Currado and his wife. Enraged, Currado imprisoned them, intending to kill them. His wife, however, persuaded him to spare their lives, and they were kept in harsh conditions. After a year, Giannotto heard of King Pedro of Aragon's rebellion in Sicily against King Charles. He sighed, lamenting his imprisonment, as his father Arrighetto Capece had been a lord in Sicily. His gaoler reported this to Currado.

Currado, realizing Giannotto's true identity, spoke to Madam Beritola, who confirmed she had a son named Giusfredi, now twenty-two. Currado saw a way to redeem his daughter's honor and do a great mercy. He questioned Giannotto, confirming his identity, and offered him Spina's hand in marriage, along with wealth and status. Giannotto, despite his imprisonment, accepted, affirming his love for Spina. Currado, impressed by his spirit, embraced him and arranged the marriage.

To gladden their mothers, Currado revealed the news. Beritola, hearing of her son's marriage, recognized Giannotto by an "occult virtue" and embraced him, fainting from joy. They recounted their misfortunes. Giusfredi then asked Currado to find his brother Scacciato and his father Arrighetto. Messengers were sent to Genoa and Sicily. In Genoa, Messer Guasparrino d'Oria, hearing the full story from the nurse (who now revealed the truth), was amazed. To amend his mean usage of Scacciato, he married him to his own daughter and brought them to Currado's castle.

The family's reunion was joyous. The messenger from Sicily arrived, reporting that Arrighetto Capece had been freed during the revolt, made a captain, and restored to his honors by King Pedro. He had sent a brigantine for his wife and sons. The family, including Spina, embarked for Sicily, where Arrighetto received them with immense joy. They all lived happily, remembering God's mercy and gratitude.

**Story 7: Alatiel (Pamfilo)**
Pamfilo tells of Alatiel, daughter of Soldan Berminedab of Babylon, renowned as the most beautiful woman of her time. She was promised in marriage to the King of Algarve as a reward for his service. She embarked on a ship with an honorable company and rich dowry. Near Majorca, a violent storm struck. The sailors, fearing the ship would sink, abandoned it in a shallop, which then foundered, killing them all. Alatiel and her women, unconscious, were left on the waterlogged ship.

The ship eventually stranded on Majorca. Alatiel awoke to find her companions dead or dying. A gentleman, Pericone da Visalgo, discovered the ship and brought Alatiel and the most precious goods ashore. He was captivated by her beauty and, unable to communicate with her, resolved to marry or seduce her. Alatiel, realizing she was among Christians and unable to reveal her identity, resolved to protect her chastity and instructed her remaining women to do the same. Pericone, frustrated by her resistance, decided to use cunning. Knowing she enjoyed wine (forbidden by her law), he plied her with it at a supper. Intoxicated, she danced and then, unashamed, undressed and went to bed. Pericone joined her, and she, having never known a man, found pleasure in his embraces. She then willingly sought his company.

Pericone's brother, Marato, also fell in love with Alatiel. He plotted with two Genoese shipmasters to abduct her. They secretly entered Pericone's house, killed him in his sleep, and carried off Alatiel and many valuables. They embarked for Chiarenza in Roumelia. Marato comforted Alatiel, and she soon became familiar with him. However, the two Genoese shipmasters also became enamored of her. They conspired, threw Marato overboard, and then argued over who would possess her. They fought, one killing the other and the survivor being grievously wounded.

Alatiel, now alone and fearing the dead man's kinsmen, went ashore with the wounded shipmaster to an inn in Chiarenza. Her beauty attracted the Prince of Morea, who was instantly smitten. The wounded man's kinsmen, hearing of the Prince's desire, sent Alatiel to him. The Prince, impressed by her royal manners, treated her as his wife. Her beauty became famous throughout Roumelia. The Duke of Athens, the Prince's kinsman, came to see her and also fell deeply in love. Overcome by passion, he conspired with a chamberlain, Ciuriaci, to kill the Prince. They stabbed the Prince and threw him and Ciuriaci (whom they also killed) from a window into the sea. The Duke then lay with Alatiel, who thought him to be the Prince. He then abducted her to a country house near Athens, keeping her secret from his wife.

The Prince's death was discovered, and the Duke was suspected. The new Prince (the dead Prince's brother) declared war on the Duke. The Emperor of Constantinople sent his son Constantine and nephew Manuel to aid the Duke. The Duchess, Constantine's sister, complained to them about the Duke's secret mistress. Constantine, hearing of Alatiel's beauty, also desired her. Feigning illness, he returned to Athens, then conspired with the Duchess to abduct Alatiel, ostensibly to remove the source of her husband's infidelity. He seized Alatiel from the garden and took her by ship to Chios.

In Chios, Alatiel again found solace with Constantine. However, Osbech, King of the Turks, attacked Chios, capturing Alatiel and Constantine. Osbech, captivated by Alatiel's beauty, married her. Meanwhile, the Emperor of Constantinople allied with Bassano, King of Cappadocia, against Osbech. Osbech went to war, leaving Alatiel with his servant Antiochus. Antiochus, falling in love with Alatiel, began an affair with her. When Osbech was defeated and killed, Antiochus and Alatiel fled to Rhodes with valuables. Antiochus then fell ill and, on his deathbed, entrusted Alatiel and his possessions to a Cypriot merchant, his friend. The merchant, taking Alatiel to Cyprus, claimed her as his wife. During the journey, they also became lovers.

In Baffa, Cyprus, Alatiel was seen by Antigonus, an old gentleman who had served her father. She recognized him and revealed her true identity and her misfortunes. Antigonus, realizing her royal lineage, promised to restore her to her father and the King of Algarve. He advised her to tell a fabricated story of her journey, omitting her many lovers, claiming she was shipwrecked, rescued by Christians, and lived chastely in a convent. The King of Cyprus, at Antigonus's request, sent her back to the Soldan. Alatiel, following Antigonus's instructions, told her false story. Antigonus corroborated it, emphasizing her chastity. The Soldan, overjoyed, sent her to the King of Algarve. Alatiel, having lain with eight men, was presented as a virgin and married the King of Algarve, living happily with him. Pamfilo concludes, "Lips for kissing forfeit no favour; nay, they renew as the moon doth ever."

**Story 8: The Count of Antwerp (Elisa)**
Elisa tells of Gautier, Count of Antwerp, appointed vicar-general of France by the King and his son, who were at war with the Germans. Gautier, a handsome and accomplished gentleman, was entrusted with the care of the queen and the king's daughter-in-law. The daughter-in-law, young and lusty, fell passionately in love with Gautier. She confessed her love to him, arguing that her wealth and leisure excused her passion, and his worth justified her choice. Gautier, a loyal gentleman, sternly rejected her, declaring he would rather die than betray his lord. Enraged, she tore her clothes and cried out that Gautier was trying to rape her.

Gautier, fearing the courtiers' envy and the lady's malice, fled immediately with his two young children, Louis (9) and Violante (7), to Calais, then to England, disguised in mean apparel. He instructed his children to keep their identities secret and to endure poverty patiently. In London, a marshal's wife, taking pity on the children, adopted Violante (renamed Jeannette). Gautier, now alone with Louis (renamed Perrot), traveled to Wales, where another marshal, impressed by Perrot's prowess in boyish sports, adopted him. Gautier then went to Ireland, taking service as a horseboy, enduring much hardship.

Jeannette grew up beautiful and virtuous, beloved by all. The marshal's son, Jamy Lamiens, fell in love with her. Believing her to be of low birth, he kept his love secret, which made him gravely ill. Physicians despaired. One doctor, observing Jamy's pulse quicken whenever Jeannette entered the room, deduced the cause. Jamy's parents, though reluctant to marry him to a commoner, agreed to give him Jeannette to save his life. Jeannette, valuing her honor, initially refused to be a mistress but agreed to marry Jamy.

Perrot, in Wales, also grew into a valiant man. A plague killed his lord, the marshal, and his family, leaving only a daughter. Perrot married her and became the new marshal.

Eighteen years after his flight, Gautier, now old and changed, returned to England to find his children. He found Perrot a great lord and Jeannette married to Jamy, both in good standing. He did not reveal himself. Jamy, taking pity on the old, poor man, hired him as a horseboy. Jamy's father, still despising Jeannette's low birth, made a disparaging remark about her children "harking back to that whence they sprang" (i.e., vagabonds). Gautier, though hurt, endured it.

The King of France died, and his son (whose wife had accused Gautier) became king. War broke out again. Perrot and Jamy led English forces. Gautier, still disguised as a horseboy, accompanied them, performing valiantly. The Queen of France, on her deathbed, confessed her false accusation against Gautier to the Archbishop of Rouen and other noblemen, begging them to restore him to his rightful place. The King, hearing this, proclaimed a reward for anyone who could find Gautier or his children.

Gautier, hearing the proclamation, revealed himself to Jamy and Perrot. Jamy, ashamed of his past insults, begged forgiveness. Gautier, still in his horseboy's attire, was presented to the King, who recognized him and, with tears, embraced him. The King restored Gautier to all his honors, making him even greater than before. Jamy received a magnificent reward for finding Gautier and his children. Jeannette and Perrot's wife joined them in Paris. Gautier, with his family, lived honorably in Paris.

**Story 9: Bernabo of Genoa (Filomena)**
Filomena tells of Italian merchants in Paris discussing their wives' fidelity. Bernabo Lomellini of Genoa boasted of his wife's unparalleled virtue and chastity. Ambrogiuolo of Piacenza scoffed, arguing that all women are naturally unstable and that a discreet woman's chastity is only a matter of secrecy. He wagered 5,000 gold florins against Bernabo's 1,000 that he could seduce Bernabo's wife within three months and bring back proof. Bernabo, confident, accepted the wager despite others' warnings.

Ambrogiuolo went to Genoa, learned about Bernabo's wife, Madam Ginevra, and found her to be as virtuous as described. He bribed a poor woman who frequented the house to hide him in a chest in Ginevra's bedchamber. For two nights, he emerged from the chest while Ginevra slept, observing the room and her person. He noted a mole under her left breast with golden hairs. He also stole a purse, a night-rail, rings, and girdles. On the third day, the woman retrieved the chest.

Ambrogiuolo returned to Paris before the deadline and claimed victory. He described the chamber and presented the stolen items. Bernabo acknowledged the description and the items but argued they could have been obtained through servants. Ambrogiuolo then revealed the mole under Ginevra's left breast. Bernabo, struck as if by a knife, instantly knew it was true. He paid Ambrogiuolo and returned to Genoa, consumed by rage.

He sent a trusted servant with letters to his wife, telling her to meet him at a country house. Secretly, he ordered the servant to kill her in a lonely place. The servant, unwilling to murder her, revealed Bernabo's command. Ginevra, swearing secrecy, persuaded him to take her clothes and present them to Bernabo as proof of her death, while she fled in the servant's doublet and hood. She gave him money and disappeared. The servant reported to Bernabo that he had killed her and left her body to wolves. Bernabo returned to Genoa, where he was blamed for his cruelty.

Ginevra, disguised as a sailor named Sicurano da Finale, took service with a Catalan gentleman. She served him so well that he took her on a voyage to Alexandria, where he presented falcons to the Soldan. The Soldan, impressed by Sicurano, requested him from his master. Sicurano gained the Soldan's favor. At a merchant fair in Acre, Sicurano saw a purse and girdle that had been hers in a Venetian merchant's shop. The merchant, Ambrogiuolo, came forward, laughing, and recounted how he won them from Ginevra and how Bernabo had her killed.

Sicurano, realizing Ambrogiuolo was the cause of her misfortunes, feigned amusement and befriended him, bringing him to Alexandria. Sicurano then arranged for Bernabo to come to Alexandria on a plausible pretext. Before the Soldan, Sicurano (still disguised) forced Ambrogiuolo to confess his deception. Bernabo, present, admitted to ordering his wife's death. Sicurano then dramatically revealed herself as Ginevra, tearing open her clothes to show the mole. The Soldan, astonished, praised Ginevra's virtue and constancy. He pardoned Bernabo at her request. Bernabo, weeping, begged her forgiveness, which she granted. The Soldan ordered Ambrogiuolo to be bound to a stake, smeared with honey, and left to die by insects. He gave Ginevra all of Ambrogiuolo's wealth and more, then sent her and Bernabo back to Genoa, rich and reconciled. Ambrogiuolo died a slow, agonizing death.

**Story 10: Paganino of Monaco (Dioneo)**
Dioneo tells of Messer Ricciardo di Chinzica, a wealthy but physically weak judge in Pisa, who married the young and beautiful Bartolomea. Ricciardo, more interested in his studies than his wife, taught her a "calendar" of saints' days, Emberdays, and other occasions when marital relations were forbidden, effectively limiting their intimacy to maybe once a month. Bartolomea was deeply unhappy.

One day, while Ricciardo and Bartolomea were fishing near Monte Nero, a famous corsair, Paganino da Mare, abducted Bartolomea in sight of her husband. Paganino, finding her beautiful and having no wife, decided to keep her. He comforted her with words, and that night, he comforted her with deeds, making her forget her husband and his "calendar." She began to live merrily with Paganino in Monaco, where he treated her honorably as his wife.

Ricciardo, learning where she was, traveled to Monaco to ransom her. He befriended Paganino, who feigned ignorance of his identity. Ricciardo, revealing his purpose, asked for his wife back. Paganino agreed, on the condition that if the lady recognized Ricciardo and wished to return, he would release her for a ransom of Ricciardo's choosing; but if she did not, he would keep her. Ricciardo, confident, agreed.

Paganino brought Ricciardo to Bartolomea. She greeted Ricciardo as a stranger, much to his astonishment. He tried to remind her of their marriage, but she, smiling, denied knowing him. Ricciardo, thinking she feared Paganino, asked to speak with her alone. Paganino agreed, with the condition he wouldn't kiss her against her will. Alone, Ricciardo pleaded with her, but she laughed and confirmed she knew him. She then bitterly recounted his neglect and his "calendar" of prohibitions, contrasting it with Paganino's constant affection and vigor. She declared she would stay with Paganino, who knew no "holidays" in bed, and would only return to Ricciardo when she was old.

Ricciardo, distraught, recognized his folly. He returned to Pisa, where he died of chagrin, constantly repeating, "The ill hole will have no holidays." Paganino, hearing of Ricciardo's death, married Bartolomea, and they lived happily, never observing any "saints' days or vigils" in their love.

**Conclusion of Day the Second**
The company laughed heartily at Dioneo's story, agreeing that Bernabo had been foolish. Filomena, her reign ended, crowned Neifile as the new queen. Neifile, after recovering from her blushes, confirmed the existing rules. She announced that the next two days (Friday and Saturday) would be dedicated to devotion and rest, as Friday commemorated Christ's passion and Saturday was for cleansing and preparing for Sunday. She proposed that on Sunday, they would move to a new location and the theme would be "OF SUCH AS HAVE, BY DINT OF DILIGENCE, ACQUIRED SOME MUCH DESIRED THING OR RECOVERED SOME LOST GOOD." Dioneo's privilege to tell any story he wished was maintained. They then enjoyed the evening with music and dancing.

**Day the Third**

**Introduction**
On Sunday morning, at dawn, the company, led by Queen Neifile, walked to a beautiful palace on a knoll, a short distance away. They admired its grand halls, elegant chambers, spacious courtyard, cool cellars, and abundant water. They then entered a magnificent walled garden, filled with trellised vines, roses, jasmine, and fruit trees, all fragrant and green. In the center was a perfectly green lawn with a white marble fountain, from which a powerful jet of water rose and flowed into channels throughout the garden, powering two mills before descending to the plain. The garden also contained many tame animals like rabbits, hares, kids, and fawns. The company agreed it was like an earthly paradise. After enjoying the garden, they dined by the fountain, then engaged in music, singing, and dancing. After a siesta, they reassembled by the fountain for storytelling. Filostrato was chosen to begin.

**Story 1: Masetto of Lamporecchio (Filostrato)**
Filostrato tells of Masetto, a young, robust, and handsome laborer. He heard Nuto, a former gardener at a convent of young nuns, complain about the low wages and the nuns' constant demands. Nuto also mentioned that the nuns were all young and seemed "possessed of the devil," implying their suppressed desires. Masetto, realizing the convent was isolated and he was young and attractive, decided to feign dumbness to get the job. He arrived at the convent with an axe, making signs that he sought alms and would cleave wood. The bailiff, impressed by his strength, hired him. The abbess, Madam Usimbalda, also saw him and, believing him deaf and dumb and therefore harmless to her "lasses," approved his employment as gardener.

Masetto, working in the garden, was often teased and spoken naughtily to by the nuns, who thought he couldn't understand. One day, two young nuns, discussing their strict confinement and the pleasures of men (which they had heard from visitors), decided to test their desires with the "mute" gardener, believing he couldn't tell. They led him to a hut, and one by one, they lay with him. They found the experience delectable. Soon, other nuns discovered their secret, and eventually, all eight nuns became Masetto's lovers.

One day, the abbess, walking in the garden, saw Masetto asleep, his clothes disarranged, revealing his body. She, too, was overcome by desire. She took him to her chamber and kept him for several days, much to the other nuns' annoyance, who complained the gardener wasn't tending the garden. The abbess also frequently sought his company. Masetto, unable to satisfy all nine women, decided to break his silence. One night, with the abbess, he spoke, complaining that one man could not satisfy nine women, and he was exhausted.

The abbess, astonished to hear him speak, asked if he was truly dumb. Masetto claimed a malady had taken his speech, and it had only just returned. The abbess, realizing the truth about her nuns, discreetly consulted them. They all confessed their secret affairs with Masetto. To avoid scandal, they agreed to pretend Masetto's speech was miraculously restored through their prayers. They made him bailiff, dividing his duties to make them manageable, and continued their discreet affairs. Masetto, having used his youth well, returned home rich and a father, without the expense of raising children.

**Story 2: King Agilulf (Pampinea)**
Pampinea tells of Agilulf, King of the Lombards, and his discreet and virtuous wife, Queen Theodolinda. A horsekeeper, a man of low birth but noble spirit and handsome, fell deeply in love with the Queen. Knowing his love was hopeless, he resolved to die, but first to try to lie with her, disguised as the King. He observed the King's routine: Agilulf would enter the Queen's chamber at night, wrapped in a mantle, with a taper and a wand, strike the door twice, and then be admitted.

The horsekeeper acquired a similar mantle, taper, and wand. After bathing to remove any tell-tale odors, he hid in the palace. When he knew everyone was asleep, he lit his taper, wrapped himself in the mantle, struck the Queen's door twice, and was admitted by a sleepy chamberwoman. He entered the bed, and feigning to be troubled (as the King sometimes was, making him disinclined to talk), he lay with the Queen several times. Then, fearing discovery, he arose, took his mantle and light, and returned to his bed.

Soon after, the King himself came to the Queen's chamber. She, thinking it was his second visit, asked, "O my lord, what new fashion is this of to-night? You left me but now, after having taken pleasure of me beyond your wont, and do you return so soon?" The King realized she had been deceived. Being wise, he chose not to expose her or himself to shame. He feigned to be capable of multiple visits and left, enraged but silent, determined to find the culprit.

He suspected it was a member of his household. He took a small lantern and went to the gallery above the stables where his servants slept. He felt each man's breast, looking for a rapidly beating heart. The horsekeeper, still awake and guessing the King's purpose, was terrified, his heart pounding even harder. The King, feeling the rapid pulse, knew he had found his man. To identify him later without causing a stir, he quietly clipped a lock of the horsekeeper's long hair. He then returned to his chamber.

The horsekeeper, realizing he had been marked, immediately arose, found shears, and clipped a similar lock of hair from every other man in the gallery. In the morning, the King ordered all his household to present themselves. Seeing most of them with clipped hair, he realized the trick. He understood the culprit's wit and, unwilling to cause a scandal for a "paltry revenge," simply said, "Let him who did it do it no more and get you gone in peace." Only the horsekeeper understood the warning. He never revealed the matter and never repeated his venture during Agilulf's lifetime.

**Story 3: A Lady and a Friar (Filomena)**
Filomena tells of a noble, witty, and beautiful Florentine lady, married to a wealthy but common wool-monger. Disdaining her husband's embraces, she fell in love with a worthy gentleman. Unable to communicate with him directly due to societal constraints and fear of discovery, she noticed he often conversed with a friar, a dull but reputedly holy man. She decided to use the friar as an unwitting go-between.

She went to the friar for confession. After confessing, she complained about a gentleman (describing her lover) who persistently pursued her, appearing everywhere she went. She claimed it caused her great annoyance and threatened her honor, and she feared telling her brothers might lead to violence. She begged the friar to rebuke him and make him stop. She also asked him to tell the gentleman that she had complained. She then gave the friar money for masses. The friar, believing her, promised to intervene.

The friar found the gentleman and, without letting him speak, sternly rebuked him for pursuing the lady, saying she had complained personally. The gentleman, quicker-witted than the friar, immediately understood the lady's clever message. Feigning shame, he promised to desist. He then went to the lady's house, where she, seeing him, showed great joy, confirming his understanding. From then on, he passed by her house frequently under various pretexts.

Later, to further inflame her lover and prove her love, the lady returned to the friar, weeping. She complained that the gentleman had intensified his pursuit, sending her gifts (a purse and a girdle). She claimed to be so angry she almost "played the devil" but had restrained herself for the friar's sake. She gave the gifts to the friar, asking him to return them and warn the gentleman to stop, or she would tell her husband and brothers. The friar, enraged, promised to "warm his ears" and took the gifts. He then angrily confronted the gentleman, who, feigning embarrassment, accepted the gifts and promised to stop.

The gentleman, overjoyed, displayed the gifts to his mistress, confirming their understanding. When her husband left for Genoa, the lady again went to the friar, weeping. She claimed the gentleman had tried to enter her chamber by climbing a tree, and she had barely repelled him. She threatened to tell her husband. The friar, furious, again confronted the gentleman, who, now fully informed of the lady's intentions, promised to stop. That night, the gentleman, using the tree, entered the lady's chamber. They made love, laughing at the foolish friar, and arranged future rendezvous without his help.

**Story 4: Dom Felice (Pamfilo)**
Pamfilo tells of Fra Puccio, a rich but ignorant man in Florence, who became a devout Franciscan tertiary. His young, beautiful, and lusty wife, Mistress Isabetta, suffered from his piety and lack of marital attention. Dom Felice, a young, handsome, and learned Conventual monk, became Fra Puccio's friend. Felice, observing Isabetta's situation, desired her. He subtly expressed his interest, and she, receptive, agreed to an affair, but only in her own house, which was difficult as Fra Puccio was always home.

Felice devised a plan. He told Fra Puccio there was a short path to sainthood, known only to a few, which he would reveal if Puccio swore secrecy. Puccio eagerly agreed. Felice instructed him to confess diligently, fast strictly for forty days (abstaining from his wife), and spend every night from complines (9 p.m.) until matins (3 a.m.) standing upright, crucifix-fashion, leaning against a plank in a place where he could see the sky, meditating on God and Christ's passion. He was to say 300 Paternosters and 300 Ave Marias. After matins, he could sleep. During the day, he was to attend three masses and say 50 Paternosters and Aves. Felice claimed this penance would purge past sins and make future venial sins easily forgiven.

Puccio, delighted, told his wife, who, understanding Felice's true intent, readily agreed to his penance, even promising to fast with him. Fra Puccio began his penance. Felice, as arranged with Isabetta, came nightly to sup and lie with her until matins, when he would leave, and Puccio would return to bed. One night, as Felice and Isabetta were making love, Fra Puccio, in his adjoining room, felt the house shake. He called to his wife, asking what she was doing. Isabetta, laughing, replied she was "tossing" because "who suppeth not by night must toss till morning light." Puccio, in his simplicity, believed her lack of sleep was due to fasting and told her to rest.

After that night, Felice and Isabetta moved their rendezvous to another part of the house. Fra Puccio continued his penance, while his wife enjoyed the monk. Isabetta often joked to Felice, "Thou hast put Fra Puccio upon performing a penance, whereby we have gotten Paradise." After Puccio completed his penance, Isabetta continued her affair with Felice discreetly. Pamfilo concludes that Fra Puccio, seeking Paradise for himself, instead sent the monk and his wife there.

**Story 5: Ricciardo, surnamed Il Zima (Elisa)**
Elisa tells of Messer Francesco Vergellesi, a wealthy but avaricious gentleman in Pistoia. He needed a handsome palfrey for his new provostship in Milan. Ricciardo, known as Il Zima, a rich but low-born young man, was desperately in love with Messer Francesco's virtuous wife. Il Zima owned the finest palfrey in Tuscany. Messer Francesco, hearing that Il Zima might give him the horse for his wife's love, sought to buy it. Il Zima offered it as a gift, on condition that he be allowed to speak privately with Messer Francesco's wife in her husband's presence, but out of earshot of others.

Messer Francesco, driven by avarice, agreed. He instructed his wife, Caterina, to listen but not to reply. Il Zima then passionately declared his undying love for Caterina, lamenting her past cruelty and begging for her pity, threatening to die if she refused. Caterina, though moved by his words and feeling a nascent love, remained silent due to her husband's command. Il Zima, realizing the husband's trick, cleverly began to speak *as if* he were Caterina, replying to himself. He said that she had always loved him but had to maintain her honor. He then promised that when Messer Francesco left for Milan, she would meet him. He instructed him to look for two napkins displayed at her garden window as a signal, and then to come to the garden door at nightfall.

Il Zima then resumed his own voice, thanking the "lady" for her gracious reply. Caterina remained silent. Il Zima then turned to Messer Francesco, saying he had spoken with a "marble statue." Messer Francesco, pleased with his wife's apparent virtue, took the palfrey. A few days later, he departed for Milan. Caterina, reflecting on Il Zima's words, her husband's neglect, and her own youth, decided to seize the opportunity. She displayed the two napkins. Il Zima saw them and that night, entered the garden, where Caterina awaited him. They made love, and their affair continued many times, even after Messer Francesco's return.

**Story 6: Ricciardo Minutolo (Fiammetta)**
Fiammetta tells of Ricciardo Minutolo, a noble and wealthy young man in Naples, who fell in love with Catella, the beautiful and virtuous wife of Filippello Fighinolfi. Catella loved her husband deeply and was fiercely jealous of him. Ricciardo, unable to win her love directly, devised a plan. He feigned despair and pretended to fall in love with another lady, publicly jousting and courting her. This convinced everyone, including Catella, that he no longer loved her. Catella, now less reserved, greeted him familiarly.

One day, at a seaside gathering, Ricciardo, alone with Catella, hinted that Filippello was having an affair. Catella, consumed by jealousy, begged him to explain. Ricciardo, extracting a promise of secrecy, told her that Filippello was trying to seduce Ricciardo's wife and had arranged a rendezvous at a bagnio (bathhouse) the next day at none (3 p.m.). Ricciardo claimed he had instructed his wife to agree but intended to send *Catella* in her place, so Catella could shame Filippello. Catella, enraged and believing him, agreed to the plan.

The next morning, Ricciardo arranged with the bagnio keeper to prepare a dark room. He hid there after dinner. Catella, full of fury, went to the bagnio at the appointed time. The keeper, following Ricciardo's instructions, confirmed Filippello was inside. Catella, with her head covered, entered the dark room and was embraced by Ricciardo, whom she believed to be her husband. She, feigning to be Ricciardo's wife, passionately made love with him.

After a while, Catella, still believing she was with Filippello, launched into a furious tirade, revealing her true identity and accusing him of infidelity and neglect, contrasting his current vigor with his usual feebleness. Ricciardo, enjoying her anger, continued to embrace her. Finally, he revealed his true identity. Catella was horrified and tried to flee, but Ricciardo held her, explaining his deception was born of love. He warned her that exposing him would ruin her honor (as he would claim she was a prostitute) and cause a deadly feud between him and her husband. He promised to be her devoted lover. Catella, though furious, recognized the truth in his words. She made peace with him, and from that day, she loved him tenderly. They continued their discreet affair, finding more pleasure in a lover's kisses than a husband's.

**Story 7: Tedaldo Elisei (Emilia)**
Emilia tells of Tedaldo Elisei, a noble Florentine youth, who loved Madam Ermellina, wife of Aldobrandino Palermini. After a period of mutual affection, Ermellina suddenly became cold and distant, refusing his messages and presence. Tedaldo, heartbroken, left Florence without telling anyone but a close friend. He went to Ancona, became a merchant, and prospered in Cyprus. Seven years later, hearing a song he had composed about his love, his desire to see Ermellina rekindled.

He returned to Florence disguised as a pilgrim from the Holy Sepulchre. He found his mistress's house closed and then saw his four brothers in mourning. He learned from a cordwainer that his brothers believed he had been murdered by Aldobrandino Palermini, who was now imprisoned, accused of killing Tedaldo for having an affair with his wife. Tedaldo was amazed that someone had been mistaken for him and grieved for Aldobrandino. That night, at his inn, he overheard three men confessing to killing a stranger, mistaking him for Tedaldo, because he had annoyed one of their wives. They rejoiced that Aldobrandino was being blamed.

Tedaldo, realizing the injustice, decided to save Aldobrandino. The next morning, he went to Ermellina's house, found her weeping, and, still disguised, told her he was a pilgrim sent by God to turn her tears to laughter and save her husband. He recounted Aldobrandino's troubles and her own history, convincing her he was a prophet. He then told her her current affliction was due to her sin of abandoning Tedaldo Elisei, whom she had loved. He explained that friars, whom she had believed, were often corrupt and sought their own gain. He argued that her actions against Tedaldo were worse than adultery, as she had robbed him of herself and effectively sought his death. He then revealed that Tedaldo was not dead but alive.

Ermellina, convinced, promised to restore her love to Tedaldo if he returned. Tedaldo then revealed his identity by showing her a ring she had given him. Ermellina, initially terrified, then joyfully embraced him. Tedaldo, promising to return that night, went to the prison. Disguised as a ghostly comforter, he told Aldobrandino that God, pitying his innocence, would save him if he forgave Tedaldo's brothers. Aldobrandino agreed. Tedaldo then went to a magistrate, revealing the true murderers (the innkeepers he overheard). The innkeepers confessed, and Aldobrandino was released, while the murderers were executed.

That night, Tedaldo returned to Ermellina, who embraced him joyfully. They made love. The next day, Aldobrandino, grateful to the pilgrim, hosted him. Tedaldo then arranged a banquet where Aldobrandino's family and Tedaldo's brothers were present. During the meal, Tedaldo revealed his true identity. His brothers, initially ashamed, embraced him. Aldobrandino, with great magnanimity, forgave them. Tedaldo then tore off his brothers' mourning clothes, and they celebrated. The truth about the murdered man (Faziuolo of Pontremoli) was later discovered, confirming Tedaldo's story. Tedaldo and Ermellina lived long and happily, discreetly enjoying their love.

**Story 8: Ferondo (Lauretta)**
Lauretta tells of an abbot in Tuscany, a holy man except for his secret affairs with women. He became close to Ferondo, a wealthy but dull-witted farmer, whose beautiful wife he desired. Ferondo, despite his simplicity, was fiercely jealous. The abbot, a clever man, invited Ferondo and his wife to the abbey garden, where he preached about eternal life. The wife, Madam Ferondo, confessed to him, complaining about her husband's jealousy.

The abbot, seeing an opportunity, told her he could cure Ferondo's jealousy by sending him to purgatory. He explained that Ferondo would "die" for a time, and after suffering penance, God would restore him to life, cured of jealousy. The wife, initially shocked, agreed, provided she didn't remarry during his "widowhood." The abbot then demanded her love as his reward, claiming it was a "sin of the body" that did not diminish his sanctity. She, after some hesitation, agreed, but only after Ferondo was in purgatory. The abbot gave her a handsome ring.

The abbot then drugged Ferondo with a powerful powder (from the Old Man of the Mountain) that induced a three-day death-like sleep. Ferondo fell asleep in the cloister, and the monks, believing him dead, sent for his wife. After a public mourning, he was buried in a tomb. That night, the abbot and a trusted Bolognese monk secretly removed Ferondo from the tomb, dressed him as a monk, and placed him in a dark prison vault, instructing the Bolognese monk to keep him there and convince him he was in purgatory.

The abbot then visited Madam Ferondo, who was in mourning, and they began their affair. He visited her often, sometimes being seen by villagers who thought he was Ferondo doing penance. In the vault, the Bolognese monk would beat Ferondo twice daily, telling him it was punishment for his jealousy. He fed him food sent by his wife (for masses), which Ferondo complained about (especially the wine). Ferondo, believing he was dead and in purgatory, promised to be a better husband if he returned to life.

After ten months, Madam Ferondo became pregnant by the abbot. To avoid scandal, they decided to "recall" Ferondo from purgatory. The abbot, using a disguised voice, told Ferondo he would return to the world and have a son named Benedict. He then drugged Ferondo again, placed him back in his tomb, and sealed it. Ferondo awoke at dawn, called out, and was found by the monks, who fled in terror. The abbot, feigning surprise, led them back. Ferondo, believing he had been resurrected, thanked the abbot, his wife, and St. Benedict. He returned home, where he was treated as one risen from the dead. He continued to tell fantastical stories of purgatory. His wife gave birth to a son, Benedict, whom Ferondo believed was his. Cured of his jealousy, he lived honestly with his wife, who continued her discreet affair with the abbot.

**Story 9: Gillette de Narbonne (Neifile)**
Neifile tells of Gillette, daughter of Master Gerard de Narbonne, who loved Bertrand, Count of Roussillon, since childhood. Bertrand was left in the King of France's care after his father's death. Gillette's father died, and she, now of marriageable age, refused many suitors, still loving Bertrand. She heard the King of France suffered from an incurable fistula. Having learned medicine from her father, she prepared a powder and went to Paris.

She offered to cure the King in eight days without pain. The King, skeptical after many failed treatments, initially refused. Gillette, however, insisted she used her father's science and God's aid. The King, deciding to try, agreed to her terms: if she failed, she would be burned; if she succeeded, she would choose a husband from his court, excluding only his sons or royal kin. Gillette cured him. She then chose Bertrand.

Bertrand, disdainful of her lower birth (she was a "she-leach"), refused. The King, bound by his promise, compelled him. Bertrand, against his will, married Gillette but immediately fled to Tuscany, joining the Florentine army against Sienna. He vowed he would only return to live with her if she had his ring (which he never removed) and a son by him in her arms – two seemingly impossible conditions.

Gillette, though heartbroken, went to Roussillon and, with great diligence, restored order to his neglected county, earning the love of his vassals. She sent two knights to Bertrand, offering to leave if her presence was the reason for his absence. He repeated his harsh conditions. Gillette, determined, left Roussillon, telling his vassals she was going on pilgrimage. She traveled to Florence, disguised as a poor pilgrim, and learned that Bertrand was having an affair with a poor but virtuous young lady.

Gillette secretly met the lady's mother, revealing her identity and misfortunes. She offered a generous dowry for the daughter if the mother would help her. The plan: the mother was to tell Bertrand her daughter would sleep with him if he sent his ring. Once Gillette had the ring, the mother would arrange a secret rendezvous, but put Gillette in the bed instead of her daughter. The mother, though hesitant, agreed. Gillette, lying with Bertrand, conceived two sons. She repeated the deception several times, collecting jewels Bertrand gave his supposed mistress.

When she was pregnant, Gillette revealed her success to the mother, who was pleased. Gillette, giving the mother a generous sum and jewels, returned to her inn. The mother then moved away, and Bertrand, hearing Gillette had left the county, returned. Gillette, after giving birth to two sons resembling Bertrand, traveled to Montpellier. She learned Bertrand was holding a festival in Roussillon. She went there, still in pilgrim's habit, and presented herself before him, revealing her sons and his ring, declaring she had met his conditions.

Bertrand was confounded but recognized the ring and his sons. Gillette recounted her entire story. Bertrand, seeing her constancy, wit, and the beautiful children, and urged by his vassals, accepted her as his lawful wife. He clothed her sumptuously, and they celebrated joyously. He honored her as his wife, and they lived happily. The story concludes that even in poor cottages, "divine spirits" can be found, and that Griselda's patience was extraordinary.

**Story 10: Alibech (Dioneo)**
Dioneo tells of Alibech, a beautiful and simple fourteen-year-old girl from Capsa in Barbary. Hearing Christians praise their faith, she asked how to serve God best. She was told that those who strictly eschewed worldly things, like hermits in the deserts of Thebais, served God best. She secretly set off alone to find a hermit. Two older hermits, fearing temptation, sent her away. She finally found a young, devout hermit named Rustico.

Rustico, wishing to test his own constancy, took her in. That night, temptation overwhelmed him. He decided to seduce her under the guise of serving God. He explained that the devil was God's enemy, and the most acceptable service was to "put the devil in hell." Alibech, innocent, asked how. Rustico stripped naked, and had her do the same. He knelt as if in prayer, and had her stand opposite him.

(The text then switches to Italian for a highly explicit passage, which is translated in a footnote by John Payne. The summary will use the translated content.)

Rustico, inflamed by her beauty, experienced "the resurrection of the flesh." Alibech, marveling, asked what the protruding thing was. Rustico called it the "devil" that gave him great annoyance. Alibech, noting she didn't have one, was pleased. Rustico then told her she had "hell" instead, and that God had sent her to him so he could "put the devil in hell" to relieve his annoyance. Alibech, in good faith, agreed. Rustico laid her on a bed and taught her how to "imprison that accursed one of God." Alibech felt a little pain at first, calling the devil an "ill thing." Rustico assured her it wouldn't always be so, and they repeated the act six times until the "devil" was "at peace."

As the "sport" continued daily, Alibech began to enjoy it, declaring that serving God was a "sweet thing" and "putting the devil in hell" was the greatest delight. She often urged Rustico, "Father mine, I came here to serve God and not to abide idle; let us go put the devil in hell." Rustico, exhausted, told her the devil was only to be chastised when it "lifted up its head for pride," and his was now "at peace." Alibech then complained that her "hell" would not leave her alone and asked Rustico to help "abate its raging." Rustico, living on roots and water, could barely keep up.

Meanwhile, a fire in Capsa killed Alibech's father and family, leaving her heir to his wealth. Neerbale, a young man who had squandered his fortune, heard she was alive. He found her and, against her will, brought her back to Capsa, where he married her and inherited her wealth. When asked by other women how she served God in the desert, Alibech (who Neerbale had not yet lain with) replied she served Him by "putting the devil in hell" and lamented that Neerbale had taken her from such service. The women, laughing, asked how, and she explained. This became a common saying in the city, and then overseas. Dioneo concludes by advising all young ladies needing God's grace to learn to "put the devil in hell."

**Conclusion of Day the Third**
Dioneo's story caused much laughter. The queen, her reign ended, crowned Filostrato, joking that they would see if the "wolf" (Filostrato) could govern the "ewes" (ladies) better than the ewes had governed the wolves. Filostrato, laughing, accepted the crown and set the theme for the next day: "OF THOSE WHOSE LOVES HAVE HAD UNHAPPY ENDINGS," as he expected an unhappy end to his own love. They then enjoyed the garden, some chasing animals, others playing chess or singing. After supper, Lauretta sang a plaintive song about lost love and regret, which was interpreted differently by various listeners. The king then dismissed them to rest.

**Day the Fourth**

**Introduction (Author's Defense)**
The author begins with a lengthy defense against critics. He notes that envy attacks even humble works. He addresses specific criticisms:
1.  **Pleasing women too much:** He confesses he enjoys pleasing women and finds them pleasing, especially their beauty, grace, and courtesy. He argues that if a hermit's son, raised in isolation, was instantly captivated by women, how can he, whose body was "created all apt to love," be blamed?
2.  **Age inappropriateness:** He dismisses this, saying that "the leek hath a white head, the tail thereof is green" (implying he is still vigorous). He cites famous poets (Guido Cavalcanti, Dante Alighieri, Messer Cino da Pistoja) who honored women in their old age. He states that women are like the Muses, inspiring him to poetry.
3.  **Peddling baubles/feeding on wind:** He sarcastically suggests these critics would tell him to "seek bread among thy fables" if he asked them for it. He points out that poets have found more wealth in fables than rich men in treasures, and that many who seek too much bread perish miserably. He asserts his self-sufficiency.
4.  **Inaccuracy of stories:** He challenges critics to produce "originals" to prove his stories are false.

He concludes by stating that his stories, like all things, can be used for good or ill depending on the reader's disposition. He defends his "unseemly" language as natural and appropriate for the setting (gardens, not churches). He argues that his stories are for "idle women" to pass time, not for scholars, and that his use of "quips and cranks" is justified by the example of friars' sermons. He admits to writing the truth about friars, which might offend some, but says he will leave each to their own opinion. He thanks God and his readers.

He then describes the morning activities: the company arises at dawn, enjoys the garden, dines, rests, and reassembles by the fountain. Filostrato, as king, bids Fiammetta begin the day's stories, whose theme is "unhappy endings."

**Story 1: Tancred and Ghismonda (Fiammetta)**
Fiammetta tells of Tancred, Lord of Salerno, a humane prince who, in his old age, had one beloved daughter, Ghismonda. He delayed marrying her, and after a brief marriage, she returned a widow. Ghismonda, beautiful, young, and sprightly, secretly fell in love with Guiscardo, a low-born but noble-hearted serving-man. Their love was mutual. Ghismonda devised a secret way for them to meet: a hidden staircase from her chamber to a grotto, which had a tunnel to the outside. Guiscardo used a rope to enter. They met many times in her chamber.

One day, Tancred, visiting his daughter's chamber while she was in the garden, fell asleep on a hassock, hidden by the bed curtains. Ghismonda, unaware, entered with Guiscardo. They made love on the bed. Tancred awoke and witnessed their act. He kept silent, then left unseen, heartbroken and enraged. That night, Guiscardo was seized as he left the tunnel and brought to Tancred. Tancred, weeping, confronted Guiscardo, who simply replied, "Love can far more than either you or I." Guiscardo was imprisoned.

The next day, Tancred confronted Ghismonda, weeping, expressing his sorrow and shame that she had chosen a low-born man. Ghismonda, realizing her secret was out and Guiscardo was captured (and likely dead), composed herself. Undaunted, she defended her love, arguing that her natural desires, her father's delay in remarrying her, and Guiscardo's true nobility justified her actions. She scorned her father's focus on social status over true worth. She challenged him to inflict his cruelty on her, for she would not beg. She declared that whatever he did to Guiscardo, she would do to herself.

Tancred, though moved by her spirit, ordered Guiscardo to be secretly strangled and his heart brought to him. He then sent the heart to Ghismonda in a golden bowl, with a message: "Thy father sendeth thee this, to solace thee of the thing thou most lovest, even as thou hast solaced him of that which he loved most." Ghismonda, who had prepared a poison, received the bowl calmly. She praised her father for a "sepulchre less of worth than one of gold" for such a heart. She kissed the heart, thanked her father for this "last gift," and lamented that she could only see it with her physical eyes, not her mind. She spoke to the heart, saying her soul would soon join his. She then poured the poisoned water over the heart, drank it all, and lay on her bed, pressing the heart to her breast, awaiting death.

Her women, alarmed, sent for Tancred. He arrived too late, finding her dying. She told him to save his tears for a less desired fate. Her last request was to be buried openly with Guiscardo's body. She died, holding the heart. Tancred, repenting his cruelty, buried them honorably in the same tomb, amidst the mourning of Salerno.

**Story 2: Fra Alberto (Pampinea)**
Pampinea tells of Fra Alberto, a wicked and hypocritical Minor Friar in Venice, who had a reputation for sanctity. He was a great preacher, often weeping during mass, but secretly a thief, pimp, forger, and murderer. He gained influence as a confessor and trustee of wills. One day, a vain and simple young lady, Madam Lisetta da Ca Quirino, confessed to him, boasting of her celestial beauty. Fra Alberto, realizing her folly, was instantly smitten and decided to seduce her.

He later visited her, claiming that the Angel Gabriel had appeared to him in a dream, chastising him for disparaging Lisetta's beauty and beating him severely. The angel, he said, loved Lisetta and wished to visit her, but would come in human form to avoid frightening her. Lisetta, believing this, was overjoyed. She agreed to receive the "angel" and, at Fra Alberto's suggestion, allowed him to use his body as a vessel, so his soul could go to Paradise while the angel possessed him. She only stipulated that the angel should not leave her for the Virgin Mary. She left her door open for him.

Fra Alberto, after fortifying himself with food, disguised himself as an angel and visited Lisetta. They made love, and he told her fantastical stories of heaven. Lisetta, delighted, believed she had lain with the Angel Gabriel. She later told Fra Alberto that she had given the "angel" a kiss under his left breast, leaving a mark. Fra Alberto continued his visits.

However, Lisetta, in a dispute with a gossip, boastfully revealed that the Angel Gabriel was her lover. The gossip spread the story throughout Venice. Lisetta's brothers-in-law, hearing this, decided to catch the "angel." Fra Alberto, getting wind of the trap, fled Lisetta's chamber by jumping into the Grand Canal. He swam to the other side and sought refuge with a poor man, telling him a fabricated story. The poor man, needing to go out, hid Fra Alberto in his bed.

The brothers-in-law, finding the "angel's wings" (his disguise) but no angel, were furious. The poor man, returning from the Rialto, heard the rumors of the angel's escape and realized Fra Alberto was the culprit. He extorted 50 ducats from Fra Alberto. He then suggested a plan for escape: on a festival day, he would disguise Fra Alberto as a "wild man of the woods" for a public hunt in St. Mark's Square. Fra Alberto, terrified, agreed. The man smeared him with honey, covered him with down, chained him, and put a mask on him. He then proclaimed that the Angel Gabriel would be shown.

In St. Mark's Square, the man unmasked Fra Alberto, revealing him to the jeering crowd. Fra Alberto was recognized, cursed, and pelted with filth. His brethren rescued him and took him to the convent, where he died in prison. Pampinea concludes that Fra Alberto, who feigned sanctity, was publicly shamed for his wickedness.

**Story 3: Three Young Men and Three Sisters (Lauretta)**
Lauretta tells of three sisters in Marseilles: Ninetta, Maddalena, and Bertella. Ninetta loved Restagnone, a poor gentleman, and they had a secret affair. Two rich young men, Folco and Ughetto, fell in love with Maddalena and Bertella, respectively. Restagnone, seeing an opportunity, proposed to Folco and Ughetto that they pool their wealth, make him a third partner, and flee to Crete with the three sisters. The young men, inflamed by love, agreed. Ninetta convinced her sisters. They stole money and jewels from their father and embarked on a brigantine for Crete. They bought estates near Candia and lived lavishly.

However, Restagnone, sated by Ninetta's constant availability, grew weary of her. He fell in love with a local noblewoman. Ninetta, consumed by jealousy, reproached him, but this only fueled his new passion. Blinded by rage, Ninetta sought revenge. She obtained a deadly poison from an old Greek woman and gave it to Restagnone, who died that night. The others mourned him, unaware of the poison.

Later, the old woman was arrested for another crime and confessed to compounding the poison for Ninetta. The Duke of Crete, learning this, secretly arrested Ninetta, who confessed. Folco and Ughetto tried to save her from being burned, but the Duke was resolute. Maddalena, who the Duke had long courted, offered herself to him in exchange for Ninetta's life and secrecy. The Duke agreed. He feigned to put Ninetta in a sack and sink her at sea, then brought her to Maddalena. The next morning, he released Ninetta to Maddalena, warning her to send Ninetta away.

Folco and Ughetto, believing Ninetta drowned, were released. Folco soon discovered Ninetta hidden in the palace. Maddalena, forced to confess the truth, enraged Folco, who drew his sword and killed her. Fearing the Duke's wrath, he fled with Ninetta, taking what little money he could. They embarked on a vessel and disappeared. Maddalena's murder was discovered, and Ughetto and Bertella were accused. They bribed their captors and fled to Rhodes, where they lived and died in poverty.

**Story 4: Gerbino (Elisa)**
Elisa tells of Gerbino, grandson of King Guglielmo II of Sicily, renowned for his prowess. His fame reached the daughter of the King of Tunis, a beautiful and noble princess, who fell in love with him by hearsay. Gerbino, hearing of her beauty, also fell in love. They exchanged messages and gifts, planning to meet.

The King of Tunis, however, betrothed his daughter to the King of Granada. The princess sent a message to Gerbino, challenging him to prove his valor. Gerbino, knowing his grandfather had pledged safe passage to the King of Tunis, was conflicted but, driven by love, armed two galleys and sailed to Sardinia to intercept the princess's ship. He found her ship becalmed. He rallied his men, promising them all the riches if he could have the princess.

He hailed the ship, demanding the princess. The Saracens, showing King Guglielmo's glove as a sign of safe passage, refused. Gerbino, seeing the princess on deck, was further inflamed. He replied that "there were no falcons there at that present and consequently there needed no gloves," and attacked. After a fierce battle, Gerbino set fire to the ship. The Saracens, seeing no escape, brought the princess on deck and, before Gerbino's eyes, butchered her and threw her into the sea, saying, "Take her; we give her to thee, such as we may and such as thine unfaith hath merited."

Gerbino, enraged, boarded the burning ship, slew many Saracens, and rescued what goods he could. He then retrieved the princess's body from the sea, wept over it, and buried it honorably on the island of Ustica. He returned home, a broken man. The King of Tunis complained to King Guglielmo, who, unable to deny the breach of faith, condemned Gerbino to death. Despite pleas from his barons, King Guglielmo had Gerbino beheaded, choosing to uphold his word over his lineage. Thus, both lovers died miserably without having enjoyed their love.

**Story 5: Lisabetta (Filomena)**
Filomena tells of three wealthy merchant brothers in Messina and their beautiful sister, Lisabetta. Lisabetta fell in love with Lorenzo, a handsome young Pisan who managed their affairs. Their love was mutual and secret. One night, the eldest brother saw Lisabetta going to Lorenzo's bed. He told his brothers, and they decided to silently eliminate Lorenzo to avoid scandal. They feigned a pleasure trip, took Lorenzo to a lonely place, murdered him, and buried him. They told Lisabetta he had been sent away on business.

Lisabetta, distraught by Lorenzo's prolonged absence, repeatedly questioned her brothers. One day, one brother angrily told her to stop asking. Lisabetta, sad and fearful, ceased questioning but continued to mourn. One night, Lorenzo appeared to her in a dream, pale and disheveled, revealing that her brothers had murdered him and showing her his burial place. She awoke, weeping, believing the dream.

The next morning, she obtained permission to go outside the city for recreation. With her maid, she went to the spot from her dream, dug, and found Lorenzo's body, still uncorrupted. Unable to move the whole body, she cut off his head, wrapped it in a napkin, and carried it home in her maid's lap. She then buried the head in a pot of basil, which she watered daily with her tears, rose water, and orange-flower water. She sat by the pot, gazing at it amorously, weeping profusely. The basil flourished, growing fair and sweet-scented from the decaying head.

Neighbors noticed her constant mourning over the pot and told her brothers. They, having already reproached her in vain, secretly took the pot away. Lisabetta, frantic, demanded its return and wept incessantly until she fell ill. In her sickness, she only asked for the basil pot. Her brothers, suspicious, emptied the pot and found Lorenzo's head. Terrified of discovery, they buried the head and secretly fled Messina for Naples. Lisabetta, never ceasing her lamentations, died weeping. Her ill-fated love thus ended. The story became a famous song.

**Story 6: Andrevuola (Pamfilo)**
Pamfilo tells of Andrevuola, a noble and beautiful young woman in Brescia, who secretly married Gabriotto, a handsome but low-born man. They often met in her father's garden. One night, Andrevuola dreamt she was with Gabriotto in the garden, but a dark, frightful thing emerged from his body, tore him from her, and carried him underground. She awoke, relieved it was a dream, but fearful. Gabriotto, however, scoffed at dreams, recounting his own dream of a black greyhound tearing out his heart. He dismissed both dreams as meaningless.

Later that night, as they sat by a fountain in the garden, Gabriotto suddenly sighed, embraced her, and cried, "Alas, my soul, help me, for I die!" He fell to the ground and died, his body swelling and discoloring. Andrevuola, distraught, wept over him. Her maid, privy to their love, came. Andrevuola, determined to preserve her honor and bury Gabriotto, refused to kill herself. She decided to lay his body before his own house. She dressed him in a silk cloth, covered him with roses, and placed her wedding ring on his finger. She and her maid carried him out of the garden.

As they carried the body, they were intercepted by the Provost's officers. Andrevuola, recognizing them, declared her innocence and willingness to explain. Physicians confirmed Gabriotto died of a burst internal imposthume, not violence. The Provost, seeing her beauty, tried to force her to his will in exchange for her freedom. Andrevuola, indignant, fiercely defended herself. Meanwhile, her father, Messer Negro, arrived at the palace, demanding his daughter. The Provost, to avoid being accused of violence, praised Andrevuola's constancy and offered to marry her himself. Andrevuola, throwing herself at her father's feet, confessed her secret marriage to Gabriotto and begged forgiveness.

Messer Negro, a kind man, wept and forgave her, lamenting that he had not known Gabriotto while he lived. He ordered a grand funeral for Gabriotto. The young man's kinsmen arrived, and the body, laid out on Andrevuola's silk cloth and covered with roses, was publicly mourned. It was honorably buried. The Provost, still desiring her, proposed marriage again, but Andrevuola, with her father's consent, became a nun in a convent, living honorably.

**Story 7: Simona (Emilia)**
Emilia tells of Simona, a poor but beautiful Florentine girl who spun wool. She fell in love with Pasquino, a young wool-monger's employee. Their love was mutual and they often met. One day, Pasquino invited Simona to a garden for a secret rendezvous. She went with her friend Lagina, meeting Pasquino and his friend Stramba. While Stramba and Lagina paired off, Simona and Pasquino sat by a sage bush. Pasquino plucked a sage leaf and rubbed it on his teeth, saying it cleaned them. Soon after, he changed countenance, lost speech, and died, his face and body swelling and darkening.

Simona, weeping, called Stramba and Lagina. Stramba, seeing Pasquino's swollen body, immediately accused Simona of poisoning him. Neighbors, hearing the commotion, also concluded she was guilty. Simona was taken to the Provost's palace. The judge, finding no evidence of malice, decided to inspect the body and the scene. At the garden, Simona recounted the events. To demonstrate, she rubbed a sage leaf on her own teeth. She immediately suffered the same fate as Pasquino, dying on the spot.

The judge and bystanders were astonished. They concluded the sage was poisonous. The garden keeper cut down the bush, revealing a "toad of marvellous bigness" underneath, whose "pestiferous breath" had made the sage venomous. The toad was burned. Pasquino and Simona, both swollen, were buried together in the church of St. Paul. The story became a song.

**Story 8: Girolamo (Neifile)**
Neifile tells of Girolamo, son of a rich Florentine merchant, Lionardo Sighieri. Girolamo grew up loving Salvestra, the daughter of a tailor. His mother, fearing he would marry beneath his station, persuaded his guardians to send him to Paris for two years. Girolamo, deeply in love, reluctantly agreed. He was kept in Paris for two years, returning more in love than ever, only to find Salvestra married to an honest tent-maker.

Girolamo was heartbroken. He tried to rekindle her memory by passing by her house, but she seemed to have forgotten him. Desperate, he resolved to speak with her. One evening, while Salvestra and her husband were out, he secretly entered their house and hid among tent cloths. When they returned and her husband fell asleep, Girolamo approached her bed and softly called her name. Salvestra, awake, was terrified and begged him to leave, reminding him she was married and desired peace with her husband.

Girolamo pleaded, recalling their past love, but she remained firm. As a last request, he asked to lie beside her to warm himself, promising not to touch her. She, taking pity, agreed. Girolamo lay beside her and, overwhelmed by his lost hope and her cruelty, "straitening in himself his vital spirits," died without a sound. Salvestra, after a while, tried to wake him, finding him cold as ice. Realizing he was dead, she was distraught. She woke her husband, fabricating a story about a stranger dying in her bed, and asked for his advice. He advised her to quietly carry the body to its own house. Salvestra then made him touch Girolamo's body.

Her husband, confounded, dressed Girolamo's body and carried it to his house, leaving it at the door. In the morning, Girolamo's death was discovered. His mother and kinsfolk mourned. Physicians found no wounds, concluding he died of grief. The body was taken to a church. Salvestra, now overcome with pity and regret, went to the church. Seeing his dead face, her old love rekindled. She shrieked, threw herself on his body, and died of grief. The cause of both their deaths became known. They were buried together in the same tomb, united in death as they could not be in life.

**Story 9: Sir Guillaume de Roussillon (Lauretta)**
Lauretta tells of two noble Provençal knights, Sir Guillaume de Roussillon and Sir Guillaume de Guardestaing, who were close friends. Roussillon's wife, a beautiful lady, fell in love with Guardestaing, and he with her. They became lovers, but their indiscretion was discovered by Roussillon. His love for Guardestaing turned to mortal hatred, but he concealed it, resolving to kill him.

Roussillon invited Guardestaing to supper, ostensibly to discuss a tournament. Guardestaing, unsuspecting, arrived unarmed. Roussillon ambushed him in a wood, crying "Traitor, thou art dead!" and killed him with a lance. He then dismounted, tore out Guardestaing's heart, wrapped it in a lance pennon, and sent it to his cook, ordering him to prepare a delicious dish from it for supper.

At dinner, Roussillon's wife, wondering why Guardestaing hadn't arrived, was told he would come tomorrow. The cook served the heart as a ragout. The lady, finding it delicious, ate it all. Roussillon then revealed that she had eaten the heart of Sir Guillaume de Guardestaing, whom she loved. The lady was horrified. She condemned Roussillon's baseness, declaring that no other food should follow such a noble meal. She then threw herself backward from a high window, dying instantly.

Roussillon, dismayed, fled. The next day, the bodies were found. Guardestaing's people and the lady's kinsfolk buried them together in the same sepulchre, with verses recounting their tragic story.

**Story 10: A Physician's Wife (Dioneo)**
Dioneo tells of Master Mazzeo della Montagna, an elderly, famous surgeon in Salerno, who married a beautiful young woman. He was neglectful in bed, claiming marital relations required long recovery. His wife, unhappy, took a lover, Ruggieri da Jeroli, a noble but disreputable young man. She helped him financially, hoping to reform him.

One day, the doctor prepared a powerful sleeping draught for a patient. He left it in his chamber. His wife, knowing he would be away, invited Ruggieri. Ruggieri, thirsty, drank the draught, thinking it was water, and fell into a deep, death-like sleep. The wife, finding him unresponsive, believed him dead. Fearing scandal, she called her maid. The maid suggested they put him in a chest outside a neighbor's carpenter shop, hoping he would be mistaken for a victim of a street brawl. The wife refused to wound him but agreed to the chest.

Two usurers, needing furniture, stole the chest that night, believing it empty, and took it to their house. Ruggieri awoke in the chest, confused. He accidentally overturned it, escaping. The usurers' wives, hearing the noise, cried "Thieves!" Neighbors and officers arrived, catching Ruggieri. He confessed to being a thief (to explain his presence), and the governor prepared to hang him.

The news spread. The wife and maid were distraught. The doctor returned, discovered his sleeping draught missing, and realized Ruggieri had drunk it. The maid, instructed by her mistress, confessed to the doctor that she had brought Ruggieri into the house, given him the water (unknowingly drugged), and put him in the chest. The doctor, amused, forgave her. The maid then went to the magistrate, repeating her story, adding details about the carpenter and usurers, explaining how Ruggieri ended up in the chest. The magistrate, confirming the story with the doctor, carpenter, and usurers, released Ruggieri and fined the usurers for theft. Ruggieri was overjoyed, and his mistress continued their affair, laughing at the whole incident.

**Conclusion of Day the Fourth**
The ladies laughed heartily at Dioneo's story, recovering from the melancholy of the previous tales. Filostrato, his reign ended, crowned Fiammetta as queen, asking her to console the company with joyous stories. Fiammetta, with her golden hair and radiant face, accepted and set the theme for the fifth day: "OF THAT WHICH HATH HAPPILY BETIDED LOVERS AFTER SUNDRY CRUEL AND MISFORTUNATE ADVENTURES." After consulting the seneschal, she dismissed the company. They enjoyed the garden, some by the mills, until supper. After supper, Filomena led a dance, and Fiammetta commanded Filostrato to sing a song. He sang a plaintive song about betrayed love and lost faith, revealing his own unhappiness. The company then retired to bed.

**Day the Fifth**

**Introduction**
At dawn, Fiammetta and her company arose, walked in the dewy fields, and enjoyed birdsong. As the sun grew hot, they returned to the palace, refreshed themselves, and spent time in the garden. After dinner and a siesta, they reassembled by the fountain. Fiammetta, as queen, asked Pamfilo to begin the "fair-fortuned stories."

**Story 1: Cimon (Pamfilo)**
Pamfilo tells of Aristippus, a noble and rich gentleman in Cyprus, whose son, Galesus, was a dullard, nicknamed Cimon (brute beast). Aristippus sent Cimon to a country house. One day, Cimon found a beautiful maiden, Iphigenia, asleep by a spring. He was instantly captivated. This sight awakened his intelligence and refined his manners. He returned to his father, demanding fine clothes and education. Driven by love for Iphigenia, he quickly became a skilled philosopher, musician, and warrior, transforming from a "dunce into a man."

Cimon, now a distinguished gentleman, sought Iphigenia's hand, but her father, Cipseus, had promised her to Pasimondas, a nobleman from Rhodes. When the wedding day approached, Cimon resolved to have her or die. He secretly equipped a ship and intercepted Iphigenia's vessel at sea. He boarded the ship, fighting fiercely, and captured Iphigenia, letting the Rhodians go. He comforted Iphigenia, telling her he, Cimon, had won her through love, not Pasimondas by promise.

Cimon and his companions sailed for Crete, where they had kinsmen. However, a violent storm struck. Iphigenia cursed Cimon's love, believing the gods were punishing his presumption. The storm drove them to Rhodes, near where the other Rhodian ship had taken shelter. They were recognized by the Rhodian sailors, who alerted Pasimondas. Cimon and his men were captured and imprisoned. Pasimondas sought their execution, but their lives were spared in return for Cimon's earlier release of the Rhodian sailors.

Meanwhile, Pasimondas's brother, Ormisdas, was to marry Cassandra, whom Lysimachus (the chief magistrate of Rhodes) loved. Lysimachus, desperate, decided to abduct Cassandra. He realized Cimon, a fellow lover, would be his best ally. He secretly met Cimon in prison, proposing they abduct their respective mistresses on the wedding day. Cimon eagerly agreed.

On the wedding day, while the festivities were in full swing, Lysimachus, Cimon, and their armed companions stormed Pasimondas's house. They seized Iphigenia and Cassandra, killing Pasimondas and Ormisdas in the ensuing chaos. They fled to their ship and sailed to Crete, where they were welcomed. Cimon married Iphigenia, and Lysimachus married Cassandra. After some exile, their friends reconciled them with their families, and they returned home, living long and happily.

**Story 2: Costanza (Emilia)**
Emilia tells of Costanza, a beautiful maiden from Lipari, who loved Martuccio Gomito, a worthy young man. Her father refused their marriage due to Martuccio's poverty. Martuccio, vowing to return rich, became a corsair. He prospered but, seeking too much, was captured by Saracens and imprisoned in Tunis. News reached Lipari that he and his crew had drowned.

Costanza, heartbroken, resolved to die. Unable to commit suicide directly, she secretly boarded a small, unattended fishing boat and set it adrift, hoping it would sink or crash. Instead, a gentle wind carried her to Susa in Barbary. A poor woman, Carapresa, found her and, taking pity, brought her to her hut. Costanza, hearing Carapresa was from Trapani, felt a flicker of hope. She was taken to a good Saracen lady, where she learned the local language and worked.

Meanwhile, Martuccio, in prison, learned of a war between the King of Tunis and a Granadan prince. He offered the King strategic advice: to use thinner bowstrings and arrows with narrow notches. This would allow the King's archers to use both their own and the enemy's arrows (whose notches would be wide enough), while the enemy could only use their own. The King followed his advice and won the war, making Martuccio a favorite and wealthy.

Costanza, hearing of Martuccio's success, felt her love rekindle. She revealed her story to the old lady, who took her to Tunis. Carapresa confirmed Martuccio's status. The old lady then informed Martuccio that a servant from Lipari wished to speak with him. Martuccio went to her house, where Costanza, overcome with joy, embraced him. They recounted their adventures. Martuccio obtained the King's permission to marry Costanza. The King, impressed, gave them magnificent gifts. Martuccio, after thanking the old lady, returned with Costanza and Carapresa to Lipari, where they married and lived happily.

**Story 3: Pietro Boccamazza (Elisa)**
Elisa tells of Pietro Boccamazza, a noble Roman youth, who loved Agnolella, a beautiful plebeian girl. His family opposed the match. Pietro, unable to marry her, persuaded Agnolella to elope with him to Anagni. They rode off, kissing and talking of love. About eight miles from Rome, they took a wrong turn into a wood. Suddenly, twelve footmen appeared from a nearby castle. Agnolella, seeing them, spurred her horse into the wood. Pietro, distracted, was captured.

The footmen, enemies of Pietro's family (the Orsini), decided to hang him. As they forced him to undress, twenty-five more footmen ambushed them. In the ensuing fight, Pietro grabbed his clothes and horse and fled into the wood, following Agnolella's path. He searched for her, weeping and calling, but found no trace. Fearing wild beasts, he tied his horse to an oak and climbed the tree to spend the night, cursing his bad luck.

Agnolella, lost in the wood, eventually found a small path leading to a hut. An old couple warned her of dangerous men in the area. She stayed, but at dawn, hearing men approaching, she hid in a hay heap in the courtyard. A band of rogues (the ones who had captured Pietro) entered, found her horse, and claimed it. One of them, throwing his lance into the hay, narrowly missed her, but she remained silent. After eating and drinking, the rogues left. The old couple, finding Agnolella, took her to a nearby castle belonging to Lionello di Campodifiore, whose wife, a kind lady, recognized Agnolella and Pietro (as a friend of her husband's). She offered Agnolella shelter, believing Pietro to be dead.

Meanwhile, Pietro, still in the oak, saw wolves devour his horse. At daybreak, freezing, he saw a fire and found shepherds, who gave him food and warmth. He told them his story. They directed him to Lionello's castle. There, he found Agnolella. Their reunion was joyful. The lady of the castle, though initially scolding Pietro for his elopement, saw their genuine love and decided to help. She married them in her castle and promised to reconcile them with their families. After enjoying their love, they returned to Rome, where the lady helped them make peace with Pietro's family. They lived happily to old age.

**Story 4: Ricciardo Manardi (Filostrato)**
Filostrato tells of Messer Lizio da Valbona, a worthy gentleman in Romagna, who had a beautiful and agreeable daughter, Caterina, late in his old age. He and his wife, Madam Giacomina, guarded her diligently. Ricciardo Manardi, a handsome young man, often visited Messer Lizio's house and fell in love with Caterina, who returned his affection. They secretly confessed their love. Ricciardo proposed they meet in the gallery adjoining Caterina's father's garden. Caterina agreed.

To achieve this, Caterina complained to her mother about the heat, suggesting she sleep in the gallery to hear the nightingale. Her father initially scoffed, saying she'd sleep to the "chirp of the crickets." But after another sleepless night for Caterina, her mother persuaded him. A bed was made in the gallery. That night, Messer Lizio locked the door to the gallery from his chamber. Ricciardo, using a ladder and handholds, climbed to the gallery, where Caterina joyfully received him. They made love throughout the night, making the "nightingale sing many a time."

As dawn approached, they fell asleep, naked and embraced, Caterina holding Ricciardo by his genitals. Messer Lizio awoke, curious to see how the nightingale had made Caterina sleep. He quietly opened the door to the gallery, drew back the curtain, and saw them. Recognizing Ricciardo, he went to his wife, telling her to come see how their daughter had caught the nightingale. Madam Giacomina, initially shocked, wanted to scold them, but Messer Lizio, calm, decided to turn the scandal into an honorable marriage. Ricciardo was young, rich, and well-born, and would make a good son-in-law.

Ricciardo awoke, terrified to be discovered. Messer Lizio, lifting the curtain, said, "We shall do well." Ricciardo begged for mercy. Messer Lizio offered him a choice: marry Caterina or die. Caterina, weeping, also urged him to marry her. Ricciardo, eager to escape death and possess his beloved, readily agreed. Messer Lizio, using his wife's ring, married them on the spot. The parents left them to rest. They continued their lovemaking. A few days later, they were formally married, and Ricciardo took Caterina home, where they lived happily, "nightingale-fowling" to their hearts' content.

**Story 5: Giannole di Severino and Minghino di Mingole (Neifile)**
Neifile tells of Guidotto da Cremona, an old Lombard soldier in Fano, who on his deathbed entrusted his ten-year-old daughter to his friend Giacomino da Pavia, along with all his wealth. Giacomino moved to Faenza with the girl, whom he loved as his own. She grew into a beautiful and virtuous fifteen-year-old.
