summary_llm:
The provided text, "The Divine Comedy," details a journey through Hell, Purgatory, and Paradise.

**HELL (OR THE INFERNO)**

**CANTO I**
The narrator finds himself lost in a gloomy, savage wood, having strayed from the direct path in a moment of "sleepy dullness." He reaches the foot of a mountain, which closes a valley that had filled him with dread. He looks up and sees the mountain's shoulders already illuminated by a planet, which brings a brief respite from his fear. He begins to ascend the lonely steep but is immediately confronted by a nimble, light panther with a speckled skin, which tries to check his progress. The hour is morning's prime, and the sun is ascending with the stars, filling the narrator with joyous hope. However, this joy is soon replaced by new dread when a hunger-mad lion appears, followed by a lean she-wolf that seems full of all wants and has made many lands desolate. The she-wolf overwhelms him with such fear that he loses all hope of ascending and is gradually driven back to a lower space.

While retreating, the narrator discerns the form of a figure whose voice seems faint from disuse. He cries out for mercy, asking if it is a spirit or a living man. The figure replies he is "Now not man, man once I was," born of Lombard parents in Mantua, and lived in Rome under Augustus. He identifies himself as a bard who sang of Anchises' son (Aeneas). He asks the narrator why he returns to such perils instead of ascending the "pleasant mount, cause and source of all delight." The narrator, abashed, recognizes him as Virgil, the well-spring of eloquence, and calls him his master and guide. He begs Virgil to save him from the she-wolf. Virgil explains that the she-wolf will suffer none to pass and is so accursed that her ravenous will is never sated. She will continue to fasten on many animals until a "greyhound" comes to destroy her. This greyhound will not live by earthly means but by "love, Wisdom, and virtue," and will bring safety to Italia's plains. Virgil then devises a plan for the narrator's profit: he will guide the narrator through an "eternal space" where he will hear despairing shrieks and see tormented spirits who invoke a second death. Next, he will see those who dwell content in fire, hoping to come among the blest. If the narrator then desires to ascend to those regions, a "spirit worthier than I" must lead him, as Virgil is adjudged a "rebel to his law" by the "Almighty King" and thus cannot enter His city. The narrator, in few words, beseeches Virgil by the God he did not adore to lead him to "Saint Peter’s gate" and those in dismal plight. Virgil moves onward, and the narrator follows closely.

**CANTO II**
As day departs and shadows darken the air, releasing all animals from toil, the narrator alone prepares for the conflict of sad pity and the perilous road. He invokes the Muses and his mind to aid his memory. He expresses doubt to Virgil, questioning his own virtue for such a high enterprise. He notes that Aeneas (Silvius' sire) and Paul (the chosen vessel) were permitted to visit the immortal tribes, Aeneas chosen as sire of Rome and its empire, and Paul traveling to bring assurance of faith. But the narrator deems himself unworthy and fears his voyage will end in folly.

Virgil, perceiving the narrator's "vile fear," explains his purpose. He was among the tribe of suspended spirits when a "dame, so blest and lovely" (Beatrice) called him. Her eyes were brighter than the sun, and she spoke with a gentle, angelic voice. Beatrice told Virgil that a friend (the narrator), "not of my fortune but myself," had met great hindrance in the wide desert and turned back through fear. She dreaded he might be past help and she risen too late. She urged Virgil to assist him with his eloquent tongue and all means for deliverance, saying it would bring her comfort. She identified herself as Beatrice, coming from a place "Revisited with joy," brought thence by Love. She promised to praise Virgil to her Master.

The narrator, delighted by Beatrice's command, asks why she is not loth to leave her ample space for the center beneath. Beatrice explains that only things from which evil may proceed are to be feared, and she is "so fram’d by God" that misery and fierce fire do not touch her. She adds that in high heaven, a "blessed dame" (implied to be Mary) mourns with such grief for the narrator's hindrance that God's stern judgment inclines to her will. This dame called Lucia, who then sped to Beatrice (seated with Rachel) and urged her to succor the narrator, who loved her so much. Lucia described his pitiful wail and the death holding him. Beatrice then came down from her blessed seat, trusting Virgil's eloquence. Virgil concludes by saying that Beatrice, Lucia, and the blessed dame plan the narrator's safety, and his words forebode certain good. The narrator's fainting vigor is restored, and he feels kindly courage. He replies, praising Beatrice and Virgil, and states his first purpose is fully resumed. He tells Virgil to lead on, as they share one will. He enters the deep and woody way.

**CANTO III**
They arrive at a portal with a dim inscription: "Through me you pass into the city of woe: / Through me you pass into eternal pain: / Through me among the people lost for aye. / Justice the founder of my fabric mov’d: / To rear me was the task of power divine, / Supremest wisdom, and primeval love. / Before me things create were none, save things / Eternal, and eternal I endure. / All hope abandon ye who enter here." The narrator finds these words hard, but Virgil tells him to leave all distrust and fear behind. Virgil then leads him into a "secret place."

Here, sighs, lamentations, and loud moans resound through the starless air, making the narrator weep. He hears various tongues, horrible languages, outcries of woe, accents of anger, and deep, hoarse voices, all forming a tumult that whirls round through the darkness, like sand in a whirlwind. The narrator asks Virgil who these people are. Virgil explains they are the wretched souls of those who lived "Without or praise or blame," mixed with a band of angels who were neither rebellious nor true to God, but only for themselves. Heaven drove them out, and Hell does not receive them, lest they glory in vain. The narrator asks what grieves them so loudly. Virgil replies they have no hope of death, and their blind life is so mean that they envy all other lots. The world has no fame of them, and mercy and justice scorn them. Virgil tells the narrator to look and pass them by.

The narrator sees a rapidly whirling flag, followed by a long train of spirits, so many that he never thought death had despoiled so many. He recognizes some, including the shade of one who, yielding to base fear, "abjur’d his high estate." The narrator understands this to be the tribe of spirits displeasing to both God and his foes. These wretches, who never truly lived, are naked and stung by wasps and hornets, whose stings bedew their cheeks with blood mixed with tears, which drops to their feet and is gathered by disgusting worms.

Looking further, the narrator sees a throng on the shore of a great stream. He asks Virgil who they are and why they seem so eager to cross. Virgil replies he will know when they reach the "woeful tide of Acheron." The narrator, with eyes cast down and filled with shame, abstains from speech until they reach the river. An old man, hoary white with age, Charon, approaches in a bark, crying, "Woe to you wicked spirits! hope not / Ever to see the sky again. I come / To take you to the other shore across, / Into eternal darkness, there to dwell / In fierce heat and in ice." He then tells the narrator, a "live spirit," to get hence and leave the dead. When he sees the narrator does not leave, Charon says he must come to shore by another way and be carried by a nimbler boat. Virgil intervenes, telling Charon not to torment himself, as "so ’t is will’d, / Where will and power are one." Charon, the boatman with "shaggy cheeks" and "eyes glar’d wheeling flames," falls silent. The spirits, faint and naked, change color and gnash their teeth upon hearing the cruel words. They blaspheme God, their parents, humankind, the place, the time, and their birth. All together, wailing, they draw to the cursed strand. Charon, a "demoniac form," collects them, beckoning, and strikes those who linger with his oar. Like light autumnal leaves, they cast themselves one by one from the shore into the umber'd wave. On the opposing bank, another throng gathers. Virgil explains that those who die subject to God's wrath all come here from every clime, eager to cross, as heaven's justice goads them and turns fear into desire. He notes that no "Good spirit" has ever passed here, and Charon's complaint about the narrator now makes sense. As Virgil speaks, the gloomy region shakes terribly, chilling the narrator's brow. The earth gives a blast, shooting forth a vermilion flame, which conquers the narrator's senses, and he drops down as if seized by sudden slumber.

**CANTO IV**
A crash of heavy thunder breaks the narrator's deep slumber, rousing him. He looks around, trying to discern his location. He finds himself on the brink of a lamentable vale, a dreadful abyss with innumerable plaints. It is dark, deep, and thick with clouds, and he cannot see its bottom. Virgil, looking pale, tells him they must descend to the "blind world." The narrator, seeing Virgil's altered hue, asks how he can speed if his guide yields to dread. Virgil explains his paleness is from pity for the anguish of the race below, not fear, and urges haste.

They enter the bounds of the first circle. Here, the narrator hears no plaint except sighs, which make the eternal air tremble, not from tortures but from grief felt by vast multitudes of men, women, and infants. Virgil explains that these spirits were "blameless" of sin, but their merit profits not, as they lacked baptism, the "portal to thy faith." If they lived before the Gospel, they did not serve God aright. Virgil states he is among them, lost for these defects, "Only so far afflicted, that we live / Desiring without hope." The narrator's heart is assailed by grief, knowing many souls of mighty worth are suspended in this Limbo. He asks Virgil if any, by their own or another's merit, ever came forth from there to be blessed.

Virgil, understanding the secret import of his speech, replies that he was new to that state when he beheld a "puissant one" (Christ) arrive, crowned with victorious trophy. This figure drew forth the shade of Adam, Abel, Noah, Moses, Abraham, King David, Israel with his sire and sons, and Rachel, exalting them to bliss. Virgil assures the narrator that before these, no human spirit was ever saved.

They continue their road, passing through the "wood" (of spirits). Not far from the summit, the narrator sees a flame prevailing over the darkened hemisphere. He discerns a tribe in high honor possessing that place. He asks Virgil who these honored ones are. Virgil replies their renown in the upper world acquires favor in heaven. A voice is heard: "Honour the bard / Sublime! his shade returns that left us late!" Four mighty spirits approach, neither sorrowful nor glad. Virgil points out Homer, bearing a falchion, preceding the others as their lord. Next is Flaccus (Horace), excelling in satire; the third is Naso (Ovid); Lucan is the last. They greet Virgil, honoring him. The narrator sees this "bright school" united, Homer soaring like an eagle. After a short discourse, they turn to the narrator, beckoning him with kind salutation. Virgil smiles, and they give the narrator greater honor, making him one of their tribe, so he is the sixth in this learned band.

They pass onward as far as the luminous beacon, speaking of matters now better left untold. They arrive at the foot of a magnificent castle, seven times begirt with lofty walls and defended by a pleasant stream, which they cross as if on dry land. Through seven gates, the narrator enters with these sages into a mead with lively verdure. There dwells a race who move their eyes majestically and bear eminent authority, speaking seldom but sweetly. They retire to an open, bright, and lofty place, where the narrator sees the great spirits by whose sight he is exalted. He sees Electra, Hector, Anchises' pious son (Aeneas), Caesar all armed, Camilla, Penthesilea, old King Latinus, Lavinia, Brutus (who chased Tarquin), Lucretia, Cato's wife Marcia, Julia, Cornelia, and, alone, the fierce Soldan. Raising his brow, he spies the "master of the sapient throng" (Aristotle), seated among philosophers, admired and revered by all. He marks Socrates, Plato (nearest to Aristotle), Democritus, Diogenes, Heraclitus, Empedocles, Anaxagoras, Thales, Zeno, Dioscorides, Orpheus, Linus, Tully (Cicero), moral Seneca, Euclid, Ptolemy, Hippocrates, Galen, Avicen, and Averroes. The narrator notes it would be vain to speak of all. The six associates part. Virgil leads the narrator another way, from that serene air into a climate vexed with storms, to a part where no light shines.

**CANTO V**
The narrator descends from the first circle to the second, a lesser space embracing more grief and provoking bitter moans. Minos stands there, grinning, strictly examining crimes. He gives sentence by coiling his tail around himself as many times as the degrees the soul must descend. Before him, a numerous throng confesses their sins, hears their fate, and is hurled downward.

Minos, seeing the narrator, cries, "O thou! who to this residence of woe / Approachest? Look how thou enter here; beware in whom / Thou place thy trust; let not the entrance broad / Deceive thee to thy harm." Virgil silences him, stating their way is "by destiny appointed" and "so ’tis will’d / Where will and power are one."

Rueful wailings begin to be heard. The narrator enters a place where "light was silent all." A bellowing noise, like a sea in tempest torn by warring winds, groans there. The stormy blast of hell drives spirits with restless fury, whirling and dashing them with sore annoy. Before the "ruinous sweep," shrieks, lamentations, moans, and blasphemies against God are heard. The narrator understands that "carnal sinners" are condemned to this torment, those in whom "Reason by lust is sway’d." Like starlings borne abroad in winter, the tyrannous gust bears these evil souls, driving them on all sides, with no hope of rest or milder pang. Like cranes chanting dolorous notes, he sees spirits wailing, hurried on by their dire doom. He asks Virgil who they are. Virgil replies the first among them was Semiramis, empress over many tongues, so shameless in luxury that she made liking lawful by decree to clear her own blame. Next, Dido, who slew herself in amorous fury. Then Cleopatra. The narrator marks Helen, Achilles (who fought for love), Paris, and Tristan, and a thousand more whom love bereft of life.

Overpowered by pity, the narrator asks to speak to two spirits coming together. Virgil tells him to note them as they approach, then entreat them "by that love which carries them along." As the wind sways them towards them, the narrator addresses them: "O wearied spirits! come, and hold discourse / With us, if by none else restrain’d." Like doves invited by fond desire, they issue from the troop where Dido ranks, speeding through the ill air. One spirit speaks, thanking the narrator for pitying their plight and offering to discourse freely while the wind is mute. She identifies her birthplace as the coast where the Po descends to the ocean. She explains that "Love, that in gentle heart is quickly learnt," entangled her companion by her fair form, taken from her cruelly. "Love, that denial takes from none belov’d," caught her with pleasing him. "Love brought us to one death: Caina waits / The soul, who spilt our life."

The narrator, hearing this, bends his looks downward for a long time. Virgil asks what he is pondering. The narrator laments the sweet thoughts and fond desire that led them to this "ill pass." Turning to them, he addresses Francesca, expressing grief and pity. He asks how love granted them to know their uncertain wishes during their sweet sighs. She replies there is no greater grief than to remember days of joy in misery. She then tells her tale: one day, they were reading of Lancelot and how love enthralled him. Alone and without suspicion, their eyes were often drawn together, and their cheeks paled. At one point, when they read of the wished smile rapturously kissed by one so deep in love, her companion (Paolo), who "ne’er / From me shall separate," at once kissed her lips. "The book and writer both / Were love’s purveyors. In its leaves that day / We read no more." As one spirit speaks, the other wails so sorely that the narrator, heartstruck by compassion, faints and falls to the ground like a corpse.

**CANTO VI**
The narrator's senses revive, having drooped with pity. He sees new torments and tormented souls in the third circle, where ceaseless, accursed, heavy, and cold showers of large hail, discolored water, and sleety flaw stream down through the dun midnight air. The land stinks. Cerberus, a cruel, fierce, and strange monster, barks like a dog through his wide threefold throat over the multitude. His eyes glare crimson, his beard is black and unctuous, his belly large, and his hands clawed, with which he tears, flays, and dismembers the spirits. The wretched, godless crew howls, spread like curs under the rain, often rolling around, screening one side with the other.

When Cerberus descries them, he opens his jaws, shows his fangs, and trembles. Virgil, expanding his palms, fills them with earth and casts it into Cerberus's ravenous maw. Like a dog that bays for food, then lets fall its fury when the morsel comes, Cerberus's loathsome cheeks drop, and he is silenced.

They pass over the shades, thrown prostrate by the tempest, setting their feet upon their emptiness. All lie extended except one, who suddenly raises himself to sit. He cries, "O thou! who through the infernal shades art led, / Own, if again thou know’st me. Thou wast fram’d / Or ere my frame was broken." The narrator replies that anguish perhaps distorts his form from remembrance. He asks the spirit's identity. The spirit replies, "Thy city heap’d with envy to the brim, / Ay that the measure overflows its bounds, / Held me in brighter days. Ye citizens / Were wont to name me Ciacco." He is worn with fatigue under the rain for the sin of gluttony, and all others here suffer like punishment for like crime.

The narrator asks Ciacco what will befall the citizens of the divided city, if any just one inhabits there, and the cause of discord. Ciacco foretells that after long striving, they will come to blood, and the "wild party from the woods" will chase the other. This party will fall within three solar circles, and the other will rise by "borrow’d force of one, who under shore / Now rests." It will oppress the other for a long space. He states that only two are just, but they are neglected. Avarice, envy, and pride are "Three fatal sparks" that have set all hearts on fire. The narrator asks to learn more, inquiring about Farinata, Tegghiaio, Giacopo, Arrigo, Mosca, and others who bent their minds on working good, asking where they bide and if heaven's sweet cup or hell's poisonous drug is assigned to them. Ciacco replies, "These are yet blacker spirits. Various crimes / Have sunk them deeper in the dark abyss. / If thou so far descendest, thou mayst see them." He asks the narrator to mention him upon returning to the pleasant world. He then says he will tell and answer no more. He turns his fixed eyes askance, eyes the narrator, then bends his head and falls among his blind companions.

Virgil explains that Ciacco will not leave his bed until the last angel-trumpet blows, when the "Power / Adverse to these shall then in glory come," and each will resume their flesh and form to hear the eternal doom. They pass through the foul mixture of spirits and rain. The narrator asks if these tortures will increase, mitigate, or remain severe after the great sentence. Virgil replies that as each thing grows to more perfection, it feels more sensibly both good and pain. Though this accursed race will never reach true perfection, they will approach it nearer then. They journey along the circuitous path, conversing, until they arrive at the point where steps lead below, finding Plutus.

**CANTO VII**
Plutus loudly exclaims, "Ah me! O Satan! Satan!" Virgil reassures the narrator and silences Plutus, telling the "Curs'd wolf" to consume himself, as their passage is willed on high. Plutus drops to the ground like sails when a mast splits.

They descend to the fourth steep ledge, gaining the dismal shore that hems in all the woe of the universe. The narrator laments Almighty Justice. He sees a wretched race, more numerous than elsewhere, leading a dance like billows on Charybdis. They roll weights with the main force of their breasts, then smite together, rolling back volubly, exclaiming, "Why holdest thou so fast?" and "And why castest thou away?" They traverse the horrid circle to opposite points, then turn and meet again in the middle. The narrator, stung with grief, asks Virgil what race this is, and if those with shorn heads on their left were separate to the church. Virgil replies that in their first life, they were so distorted in mind that they made no proper use of their wealth. This is clear from their words. Those "crowned" with no hairy cowls (Popes and Cardinals) were separate to the church, over whom avarice maintained dominion.

The narrator asks if he will recognize any stained with these foul sins. Virgil replies it's a vain thought, as their ignoble life makes them dark and indiscernible. They will forever meet in this rude shock, some rising from the tomb with clenched grasp, others with close-shaven locks. Their ill-given and ill-kept wealth deprived them of the beautiful world and set them at this strife. Virgil tells the narrator how brief and vain are the goods committed to fortune's hands, for which humanity makes such a coil. Not all the gold beneath the moon could purchase rest for one of these souls.

The narrator asks Virgil about this "fortune." Virgil explains that God, whose wisdom passes all, created the heavens and gave them ruling powers. Similarly, he ordained a "Superintendence of a guiding hand / And general minister" (Fortune) to rule over the world's bright images, changing life's empty advantages from race to race, beyond man's wisest care. One nation rises, another languishes, as Fortune's will decrees, concealed from them. Against her, human wisdom avails nothing. She plans, judges, and reigns without intermission, swift by necessity. She is execrated by those who owe her praise. She is blessed and exults in her bliss. Virgil says they must pass on to heavier woe, as the stars forbid long tarrying. They cross the circle to the next steep, arriving at a well that boils and pours itself down to a foss. The wave is murkier than the sablest grain. They enter beneath, journeying by the side of the inky waters. The dismal stream expands into a lake named Stygian. The narrator stands intent, gazing, and in the marsh, he descries a "miry tribe," naked and enraged, striking each other with hands, heads, breasts, and feet, cutting each other piecemeal with their fangs. Virgil explains these are the souls of those whom anger overcame. He adds that underneath the water dwells a multitude whose sighs make the surface heave with bubbles. Fixed in the slime, they say, "Sad once were we / In the sweet air made gladsome by the sun, / Carrying a foul and lazy mist within: / Now in these murky settlings are we sad." They gurgle this dolorous strain, but utter no distinct word. They compass their route, a segment stretched between the dry embankment and the pool, looking downward at those who gulp its muddy lees, stopping only at a tower's low base.

**CANTO VIII**
Before reaching the tower's base, they see two cressets (lights) on its height and another light returning the signal from afar. The narrator asks Virgil what this means. Virgil replies they may see what awaits them on the filthy waters if the marsh-gendered fog does not conceal it. A small bark, ferried by one, comes swiftly through the waves. The ferryman cries, "Art thou arriv'd, fell spirit?" Virgil replies, "Phlegyas, Phlegyas, / This time thou criest in vain... No longer shalt thou have us, but while o’er / The slimy pool we pass." Phlegyas pines in fierce ire. Virgil steps into the skiff, and the narrator follows. The vessel seems freighted only after the narrator enters. The ancient prow cuts the waves more deeply than usual.

While on the dead channel, one drench'd in mire comes before the narrator, asking who he is, coming before his hour. The narrator replies he comes but tarries not, and asks who the other is, so foul. The spirit replies, "One, as thou seest, who mourn." The narrator tells the "Curs'd spirit" to tarry in mourning, recognizing him even in filth. The spirit stretches hands to the bark, but Virgil thrusts him back, saying, "Away! down there, / To the other dogs!" Virgil then encircles the narrator's neck with his arms, kisses his cheek, and praises his "Justly disdainful" soul. He says the spirit was noted for arrogance in the world, and his shadow is furious here. Many who are mighty kings above will wallow like swine here. The narrator wishes to see him whelmed in dregs before they quit the lake. Virgil assures him his wish will be satisfied. Scarcely had Virgil spoken when the miry tribes set on the spirit with such violence that the narrator thanks God. They cry, "To Filippo Argenti!" and the moody Florentine turns his avenging fangs on himself. They leave him.

A sudden sound of lamentation strikes the narrator's ear. Virgil says they are nearing the city named Dis, with its mighty throng of grave denizens. The narrator sees vermilion minarets, which Virgil explains are eternal fire burning within. They come within the deep fosses that moat this comfortless region. The walls appear iron. They make a wide circuit, reaching a place where the mariner (Phlegyas) cries vehemently, "Go forth! / The entrance is here!" On the gates, the narrator spies more than a thousand fallen angels, who cry, "Who is this... that without death first felt, goes through / The regions of the dead?" Virgil signals for secret parley. Their anger abating, they say, "Come thou alone; and let him go / Who hath so hardily enter’d this realm. / Alone return he by his witless way; / If well he know it, let him prove. For thee, / Here shalt thou tarry, who through clime so dark / Hast been his escort." The narrator is terrified, believing he will never return. He begs Virgil not to desert him. Virgil replies that none has power to disappoint their passage, permitted by "such high / Authority." He tells the narrator to expect him there and comfort his spirit with hope. Virgil departs. The narrator remains, hesitating. He cannot hear the terms, but the demons confer briefly, then flee within, closing the gates on Virgil. Virgil returns with tardy steps, eyes bent on the ground, all confidence erased, sighing, "Who hath denied me these abodes of woe?" He tells the narrator not to fear his anger, as he will vanquish them. He says their insolence is not new, displayed erewhile at a less secret gate (Hell's entrance), which is still without bolt. He adds that "One whose strong might can open us this land" is coming, unescorted, down the steep.

**CANTO IX**
The narrator's pale cheeks show coward dread. Virgil, listening, cannot see far through the dark, thick air. He begins, "It yet behooves / We win this fight," then adds, "if not— / Such aid to us is offer’d.—Oh, how long / Me seems it, ere the promis’d help arrive!" The narrator notes the sequel of his words cloaked their beginning, and his fear increases. He asks if anyone ever descends to this depth from the first degree (Limbo), whose pain is merely deprivation of sweet hope. Virgil replies it rarely happens, but he once came here, conjured by the sorceress Erictho, to draw a spirit from "Judas’ circle," the lowest, obscurest place. He knows the road well. He adds that the noisome lake encompasses the "city of grief," which they cannot enter without rage.

Virgil adds more, but the narrator does not recall it, as his eye is drawn to the lofty tower. He sees three hellish furies, stained with blood, with feminine limbs and motion. Greenest hydras twist around them, and adders and cerastes creep instead of hair. Virgil identifies them as Megaera, Alecto, and Tisiphone, who tend the queen of endless woe. They tear their breasts, smite themselves, and raise a shrill clamor, making the narrator cling to Virgil. They cry, "Hasten Medusa: so to adamant / Him shall we change." Virgil turns the narrator around and covers his eyes with his own hands, warning him not to view the Gorgon, lest his return upwards be lost forever.

A loud-crashing, terrible sound comes over the perturbed waves, making both shores tremble, like an impetuous wind. Virgil loosens the narrator's eyes and tells him to direct his sight along the ancient foam where the smoke ascends thickest. Like frogs fleeing a serpent, more than a thousand destroyed spirits flee before one who passes with unwet feet over the Stygian sound. This figure, removing the gross air from his face, often stretches forth his left hand, wearied only by that annoyance. The narrator perceives he is sent from heaven and turns to Virgil, who signals him to stand quiet and bend to the figure. The figure seems full of noble anger. He comes to the gate and touches it with his wand, and it flies open without impediment. He stands on the horrid grunsel and rebukes the "Outcasts of heav’n" for their insolence, asking why they kick against God's will, which has often enforced their pangs. He reminds them that Cerberus still bears his peeled throat and maw from here. Having said this, he turns back without speaking to them, appearing beset by other cares.

They move towards that territory, secure after the hallowed words, and enter unopposed. The narrator looks around, seeing wide-stretching space replete with bitter pain and torment. Like the plains of Arles or Pola, the place is thick with sepulchres, but here, flames are scattered amidst the graves, burning so intensely that iron needs no hotter fire. Their lids hang suspended, and from beneath them issue lamentable moans. The narrator asks Virgil who is interred in these vaults. Virgil replies, "The arch-heretics are here, accompanied / By every sect their followers; and much more, / Than thou believest, tombs are freighted: like / With like is buried; and the monuments / Are different in degrees of heat." They turn to the right, passing between the afflicted and the high ramparts.

**CANTO X**
They proceed by a secret pathway between the walls and the tormented souls, Virgil first, the narrator close behind. The narrator asks Virgil if those in the sepulchres can be seen, as their lids are raised. Virgil replies they will be closed when the souls return from Josaphat with their bodies. He explains that Epicurus and his followers, who believe the spirit dies with the body, are in this part of the cemetery.

Suddenly, a voice from a vault addresses the narrator, recognizing his Tuscan speech and stating he may have dealt severely with his noble land. The narrator approaches Virgil in fear. Virgil tells him to turn and behold Farinata, who has uplifted himself from his girdle upwards, seeming to hold hell in scorn. Virgil pushes the narrator to the tomb's foot, warning him to speak clearly. Farinata eyes the narrator, then disdainfully asks his ancestors. The narrator reveals his lineage. Farinata, uplifting his brow, cries that they were fiercely adverse to him and his party, and he scattered them twice. The narrator retorts that his family returned each time, an art Farinata's family has not learned.

Then, a shade, high as the chin, rises from Farinata's side, peering forth from the unclosed jaw. It looks around for others with the narrator. Perceiving its "fond imagination quenched," it speaks with tears: "If thou through this blind prison go’st, / Led by thy lofty genius and profound, / Where is my son? and wherefore not with thee?" The narrator replies he comes not of himself, but conducted by Virgil, whom his son (Guido) perhaps held in contempt. The shade (Cavalcante de' Cavalcanti) exclaims, "How! said’st thou he HAD? / No longer lives he? Strikes not on his eye / The blessed daylight?" The narrator's delay in replying causes the shade to fall back supine, not appearing again.

Meanwhile, Farinata, great of soul, changes not his stern countenance. He continues the discourse, saying that if the narrator's family has shown small skill in returning, "that doth torment me more e’en than this bed." He foretells that not fifty times will the queen of this realm (the moon) be relumed before the narrator knows the full weight of that art. He asks why the Florentine people are so fell against his kin. The narrator attributes it to the "slaughter and great havoc" that stained Arbia's flood crimson. Farinata sighs, shakes his head, and replies that he stood not singly in that affray, but alone forbade the deed when all consented to raze Florence to the ground.

The narrator adjures him to solve another knot: if the damned view beforehand what time leads, but are uninformed of the present. Farinata answers, "We view, as one who hath an evil sight... plainly, objects far remote." God imparts this splendor. But when objects approach or actually exist, their intellect wholly fails, and they know nothing of human state except what others bring them. Therefore, their knowledge will expire when "futurity the portals close." The narrator, conscious of his fault and smitten by remorse, asks Farinata to tell Cavalcante that his offspring is still living, and that his silence was due to his thoughts being intent on the error Virgil has solved.

Virgil calls the narrator back. The narrator asks Farinata who else partakes his lot. Farinata replies, "More than a thousand with me here are laid / Within is Frederick, second of that name, / And the Lord Cardinal, and of the rest / I speak not." He withdraws. The narrator, reverting to Virgil, ruminates on the ill-betokening words. Virgil asks the cause of his amaze. The narrator satisfies the inquiry, and Virgil enjoins him to store what he has heard, and that Beatrice will unfold his future when he stands before her. They turn left, leave the wall, and go by a path that strikes to a valley exhaling noisome steam.

**CANTO XI**
They arrive at the utmost verge of a high bank, environed by craggy rocks, where more cruel woes are stored. To shun the fetid exhalation from the profound abyss, they stand retired behind a great monument. On it, the narrator marks a scroll: "I have in charge / Pope Anastasius, whom Photinus drew / From the right path." Virgil explains they must delay to accustom their senses to the dire breath. The narrator asks for some compensation for the time. Virgil replies his thoughts tend to the narrator's wishes.

Virgil explains that within these rocks are three close circles, in gradation, like those they are leaving. Each is full of accursed spirits. He will explain how and for what cause they abide in durance. Of all malicious acts, the end is injury, working woe by force or fraud. Fraud, being peculiar to man, is more displeasing to God, and the fraudulent endure severer pangs. The violent occupy the first circle, framed in three rounds, as force can be offered to God, his neighbor, and himself. Violence against a neighbor (slayers, smiters, plunderers, robbers) is in the first round. Violence against oneself and one's possessions (suicides, those who waste talent) is in the second round. Violence against God (denying/blaspheming his power, contemning nature) is in the inmost round (Sodom and Cahors).

Fraud, which leaves a sting, is employed on one whose trust is won or on another who withholds confidence. The latter breaks the bond of love nature makes, and in the second circle (of fraud) are dissimulation, witchcraft, flatteries, theft, falsehood, simony, seducers, and those who pawn honesty. The other way (fraud against special faith) forgets both nature's general love and special faith. Thus, in the lesser circle, the "point of the universe," dread seat of Dis, the traitor is eternally consumed.

The narrator finds Virgil's discourse clear, distinguishing the chasm and its inhabitants. He asks why the souls in the dull, fat pool (the wrathful and sullen) and those driven by tempest (the lustful) are not punished within the city of fire, if God's wrath is on them. If not, why are they condemned? Virgil replies, asking why his mind wanders. He reminds the narrator of the "ethic page" (Aristotle) describing three dispositions adverse to Heaven's will: incontinence, malice, and brutishness, and how incontinence offends God least and incurs least guilt. If he notes this judgment and remembers who those outside the walls are, he will discern why they are placed apart and receive less wreakful divine vengeance.

The narrator praises Virgil for healing his imperfect sight. He asks Virgil to turn back to where he said usury offends celestial Goodness. Virgil replies that philosophy clearly points out how imitative nature takes her course from the celestial mind and art. The Stagyrite (Aristotle) shows how art follows nature, deserving the name "second in descent / From God." These two (nature and art) were the right source of life and excellence. But the usurer walks another path, setting nature and her follower at naught. Virgil urges them to follow his steps, as the Pisces play along the horizon and the Wain lies over the north-west, indicating it's time for their steep passage down the rocky height.

**CANTO XII**
The precipice they reach is rough as an Alp, and on its verge lies an object every eye would shun. It is a ruin, like one struck by a stream or earthquake, where the headlong rock is shivered to give passage. Stretched at the point of the disparted ridge is the Minotaur, "the infamy of Crete," gnawing itself in rage. Virgil exclaims to it that the narrator is not the King of Athens (Theseus) but comes to behold its torments. The Minotaur plunges like a bull struck by a fatal blow. Virgil tells the narrator to run to the passage while it storms.

They take their road down through the dilapidated crags, which often move beneath the narrator's feet. The narrator ponders, and Virgil explains that when he first descended to nether hell, this rock had not yet fallen. But not long before "He arrived, / Who carried off from Dis the mighty spoil / Of the highest circle" (Christ's Harrowing of Hell), such trembling seized the deep concave that Virgil thought the universe was thrilled with love, and in that point, here and elsewhere, the old rock toppled down.

Virgil tells the narrator to fix his eyes beneath, as the river of blood (Phlegethon) approaches, in which all those who injured by violence are steeped. The narrator sees an ample foss, bent in a bow, circling the plain. Between it and the rampart's base, Centaurs, armed with keen arrows, run like hunters. At their descent, the Centaurs stop. Three speed forth, armed with bows. One cries, "Say to what pain ye come / Condemn’d, who down this steep have journied? Speak / From whence ye stand, or else the bow I draw." Virgil replies their answer will be made to Chiron when they come nearer. He touches the narrator and identifies Nessus (who died for Deianira), Chiron (who nursed Achilles), and Pholus. These Centaurs go by thousands around the foss, aiming shafts at spirits emerging from the blood.

They draw near the Centaurs. Chiron takes an arrow, pushes back his shaggy beard, and exposes his great mouth, exclaiming to his fellows, "Are ye aware, that he who comes behind / Moves what he touches? The feet of the dead / Are not so wont." Virgil, standing near Chiron's breast, replies that the narrator is alive, and must be shown the gloomy vale by him, induced by necessity, not delight. He explains that a heavenly lady (Beatrice) consigned this new office to his care. He is no robber, nor a dark spirit. He asks Chiron to grant one of his band to guide them to the ford and convey the narrator across, mounted on his back, as he is not a spirit that can walk the air. Chiron turns to Nessus and tells him to return and be their guide, commanding any other troop to keep aloof.

They move onward, Nessus by their side, along the border of the crimson-seething flood, from which loud shrieks arise. The narrator marks some immersed as high as their brow. Nessus identifies these as tyrants given to blood and rapine, wailing their merciless wrongs. He names Alexander, Dionysius, Azzolino, and Obizzo of Este (destroyed by his foul step-son). The narrator turns to Virgil, who tells him to let Nessus be his first leader. Nessus pauses near some spirits extant from the wave at the throat, and points out a spirit apart, exclaiming, "He in God’s bosom smote the heart, / Which yet is honour’d on the bank of Thames" (Guy de Montfort). The narrator next espies a race holding their heads and busts above the stream, recognizing many faces. The blood becomes shallower, imbruing only the feet, where their passage lies. Nessus explains that as the boiling wave diminishes on this side, so it sinks lower on the other, joining where tyranny mourns. Heaven's stern justice chastises Attila, Sextus, Pyrrhus, and the Rinieri (Corneto and Pazzo), who filled the ways with violence and war. Nessus turns and, quitting them, repasses the ford alone.

**CANTO XIII**
Before Nessus reaches the other bank, they enter a forest where no track of steps has worn a way. The foliage is dusky, the boughs gnarled and thick, with thorns instead of fruit, filled with venom. The narrator compares it to brakes less sharp and intricate. Here, the brute Harpies make their nest, the same who drove the Trojan band from the Strophades with dire boding. They have broad pennons, human necks and countenances, keen talons, and huge bellies fledged with wings. They sit and wail on this drear mystic wood.

Virgil explains they are in the second round, and will be until they reach the horrid sand. He tells the narrator to look around. The narrator hears sad plainings but sees no one. Virgil, believing the voices come from concealed spirits, tells him to lop off a twig to vanish his thought. The narrator stretches his hand and gathers a branch from a great wilding. The trunk immediately exclaims, "Why pluck’st thou me?" Dark blood trickles down its side, and it adds, "Wherefore tear’st me thus? / Is there no touch of mercy in thy breast? / Men once were we, that now are rooted here. / Thy hand might well have spar’d us, had we been / The souls of serpents." Words and blood burst forth from the broken splinter.

The narrator drops the bough, terror-stricken. Virgil apologizes to the "injur'd spirit," explaining the narrator's disbelief. He asks the spirit's identity, promising that the narrator, who is granted to return to the upper world, may revive his fame. The trunk replies that this "pleasant word" has inveigled him to speak. He identifies himself as one who held "Both keys to Frederick’s heart," opening and shutting with skill, so that few others could find admittance to his inmost breast. His faith to his high charge cost him his life-blood. The "harlot" (envy), who never turned her eyes from Caesar's household, inflamed minds against him, spreading the flame to Augustus, changing his honors to woes. His soul, disdainful, sought refuge in death, becoming "unjust toward myself." He swears by the new roots of his stem that he never broke faith with his liege lord. He asks that if any return to the world, they clear his memory from envy's cruel blow.

Virgil pauses, then tells the narrator to speak and ask more. The narrator replies he has no power to ask, such pity is in his heart. Virgil asks the imprisoned spirit how the soul is tied in these gnarled joints and if any are ever loosened. The trunk breathes hard, and the wind changes to articulate sounds. It explains that when the fierce soul departs the body, torn asunder, it is doomed by Minos to the seventh gulf. It falls into the wood, sprouting like a grain, growing into a savage plant. The Harpies feed on its leaves, causing pain and a vent for grief. They, like the rest, will come for their "spoils" (bodies) but cannot be clad in them, as it's unjust to have what one takes from oneself. Their bodies will be hung on the wild thorn of their wretched shade.

While still listening to the trunk, a noise surprises them, like a wild boar hunt. Two naked spirits, torn with briers, come in headlong flight, breaking every fan of the wood. The foremost cries, "Haste now, haste thee death!" The other, impatient of delay, exclaims, "Lano! not so bent for speed / Thy sinews, in the lists of Toppo’s field." He then makes one group of himself and a bush. Behind them, the wood is full of black female mastiffs, gaunt and fleet. They stick their fangs into the squatted spirit, rend him piecemeal, and bear away the tortured limbs. Virgil seizes the narrator's hand and leads him to the thicket, which mourns through its bleeding wounds, crying, "O Giacomo / Of Sant’ Andrea! what avails it thee... that of me thou hast made thy screen? / For thy ill life what blame on me recoils?" Virgil pauses, then asks the thicket who it is. It replies it dwelt in the city (Florence) that changed its first patron (the Baptist), whence he will not cease to work her woe. If not for some faint glimpse of him on Arno's passage, those citizens who rebuilt her walls after Attila would have toiled in vain. The spirit concludes, "I slung the fatal noose from my own roof" (he committed suicide).

**CANTO XIV**
Moved by charity, the narrator collects the scattered leaves and restores them to the hoarse spirit. They reach the limit dividing the second and third rounds, where a horrible contrivance of justice is displayed. They reach a wide plain of arid, thick sand, resembling the soil Cato trod. The mournful wood waves around, and the sad foss spreads around the wood. They stay their steps on the edge.

The narrator sees many flocks of naked spirits, weeping piteously, subject to different laws: some lie supine, some crouch, others pace incessantly. Dilated flakes of fire fall slowly over all the sand, like snow on Alpine summits. The marble ground glows underneath, like a stove, to augment the pain. The spirits ceaselessly ply their hands to shake off the falling heat.

The narrator asks Virgil about a huge spirit that seems heedless of the burning, lying writhen in proud scorn. The spirit, aware of the question, exclaims, "Such as I was / When living, dead such now I am." He defies Jove, saying even if Jove wearied his workman (Vulcan) and launched bolts with all his might, he would never enjoy sweet revenge. Virgil, in a higher accent, tells Capaneus that his pride, still unquenched, is his punishment. He tells the narrator that Capaneus was one of the seven kings who besieged Thebes and held God in disdain.

They pass silently to where a little brook gushes from the forest's bound, whose crimsoned wave lifts the narrator's hair with horror. It runs down through the sand, its bottom and banks stone-built, and their passage lies along its margins. Virgil says of all he has shown, nothing is so worthy of regard as this river, over which the flaming volley is quenched. The narrator asks for more knowledge.

Virgil explains that in the midst of the ocean lies Crete, where a mountain, Ida, joyful once, now deserted, was Rhea's secret cradle for Saturn's son. Within the mount stands a huge ancient form (the Old Man of Crete), turning his shoulders towards Damiata and looking at Rome. His head is gold, breast and arms silver, middle brass, and downward all steel, save the right foot of potter's clay. Each part except the gold is rent, and from the fissure, tears distil, penetrating to a cave. These tears form Acheron, Styx, and Phlegethon, then passing beneath, form Cocytus. The narrator asks why this sluice appears only now. Virgil replies the place is round, and they have not yet made the circuit of the whole orb. The narrator asks where Phlegethon and Lethe flow. Virgil says the red seething wave (Phlegethon) might have resolved one question. Lethe will be seen elsewhere, where spirits whose blame has been removed by penitence go to lave themselves. Virgil adds it is time to quit the wood and follow his steps on the safe margins, as all vapor is extinct over them.

**CANTO XV**
They walk on one of the solid margins, enveloped in mist from the stream, which saves both piers and water from fire. The narrator compares the mounds to those built by Flemings or Paduans. They are not far from the wood when they meet a troop of spirits. They eye them narrowly. One catches the narrator by the skirt, crying, "What wonder have we here!" The narrator recognizes him as Brunetto Latini. Brunetto asks if the narrator would be displeased if he turned back a little. The narrator replies he prays for it and would sit with him if Virgil permits. Brunetto explains that whoever stops for an instant lies for a hundred years in the fire. He will walk close to the narrator's garments. The narrator dares not descend to equal ground.

Brunetto asks what chance or destiny brings the narrator here and who shows him the way. The narrator explains he was lost in a serene life, met Virgil, and is now being led home. Brunetto advises him to follow his "star" for a glorious haven, unless his judgment erred in fairer days. He would have given comfort if his fate had not chanced so early. He foretells that the "ungrateful and malignant race" from Fiesole (Florentines) will show enmity for his good deeds, as sweet fig-trees do not suit ill-savored crabs. He describes them as blind, covetous, envious, proud, and warns the narrator to cleanse himself of their ways. His fortune holds such honor that he will be craved by both parties. He tells him to keep the fresh herb far from the goat's tooth, and that the Fiesole herd may make litter, not touch the holy seed of true Romans.

The narrator replies that if his wish were fulfilled, Brunetto would not have been driven from man's nature, for his dear, benign, paternal image is fixed in his mind, remembering his teaching on how to win eternity. He says he writes down Brunetto's prophecy for Beatrice to comment on. He is prepared for fortune, as his conscience has no plea against him. Virgil turns back, smiles, and says, "He listens to good purpose who takes note."

The narrator continues discoursing with Brunetto, asking who are most known among his tribe. Brunetto replies it's well to know some, but silence is best for the rest. He briefly tells that all these were clerks, men of great learning, polluted by the same sin. He names Priscian and Francesco d'Accorso. He adds that if the narrator wished to see "him who by the servants’ servant was transferr’d / From Arno’s seat to Bacchiglione," he might have. Brunetto says he must desist from further speech and onward way, as he sees a new mist rising and a company he cannot sort with approaching. He commends his "TREASURE" (writings) to the narrator. Brunetto turns and speeds away, like one who gains the prize in a race.

**CANTO XVI**
The narrator reaches where the water's din is heard, falling into the other round. Three spirits issue from a troop beneath the tormenting storm, running swiftly towards them, crying, "Oh do thou stay! / Whom by the fashion of thy garb we deem / To be some inmate of our evil land." The narrator sees recent and old wounds on their limbs from the flames. Virgil pauses, saying they merit courtesy, and were it not for the fiery darts, haste would better suit the narrator.

When they stop, the three spirits resume their wail and whirl together in a restless wheel, directing their countenances at the narrator. One begins, asking who the narrator is, who imprints Hell's soil with living feet, and says their great renown should incline him to inform them. He identifies the one following him as Guidoguerra, grandson of Gualdrada, who achieved noble acts. The next is Aldobrandi. The speaker himself is Rusticucci, brought to this evil by his savage wife. The narrator, though wishing to cast himself among them, is vanquished by fear of the dire burning.

The narrator replies that not scorn, but grief for their doom, fixed deep within him. He is a countryman of theirs, having heard their deeds and names. He is leaving the gall for the sweet fruit, guided by Virgil, and must descend to the center first. Guidoguerra asks if courtesy and valor still dwell in Florence, as Borsiere, one of their peers, brings sad news. The narrator cries, "An upstart multitude and sudden gains, / Pride and excess, O Florence! have in thee / Engender’d, so that now in tears thou mourn’st!" The three spirits look at each other, then rejoin, saying if he easily satisfies questioners, he is happy. They ask him to speak of them among mankind if he escapes this dark clime. They break the circle and flee swiftly.

Virgil pursues his track, and the narrator follows. The water's sound becomes deafening, like a river falling down a precipice. The narrator has a cord around his girdle, which he once thought to use to take the "painted leopard." Virgil bids him unloosen it. The narrator gathers it and stretches it forth to Virgil, who turns right and casts it into the deep abyss. The narrator wonders at this strange signal. Virgil says what he expects will come quickly, and the narrator's thought is dreaming. He then states that one should bar his lip from truth that seems false, but here silence is vain. He swears that through the gross and murky air, he spied a shape swimming up, like one returning from loosing an anchor, drawing in his feet.

**CANTO XVII**
Virgil points out the "fell monster with the deadly sting!" (Geryon), who passes mountains, breaks walls, and taints the world with his filth. He beckons Geryon to shore. Geryon appears, his head and upper part on land, but not his bestial train. His face resembles a just man's, kind and gracious. The rest is serpent, with two shaggy claws, and his back, breast, and sides painted with nodes and orbits, more variegated than Turks or Tartars weave. Like a skiff moored to shore or a beaver watching for prey, the fiend sits on the rim. His tail is upturned with a scorpion's sting. Virgil says they must turn towards the beast.

They shape their course to the right, walking ten paces on the verge to escape the flame and burning marl. Near Geryon, the narrator beholds a tribe of spirits seated on the sand near a wide chasm. Virgil tells him to mark their mien but hold not long discourse, as he will parley with Geryon for aid. The narrator paces alone on the extremity of the seventh circle. The spirits' pangs gush from their eyes. They ply their shifting hands against the vapours and torrid soil, like dogs fighting gnats. The narrator notes their visages, recognizing none, but perceives each bears a pouch with various emblems, on which their eye seems to feed. He sees a yellow purse with an azure lion, a red purse with a white goose, and a white scrip with a fat azure swine. The last speaker addresses him, asking what he does in this deep. He identifies himself as a Paduan among Florentines and foretells that Vitaliano will sit on his left, and they often thunder in his ears, exclaiming, "O haste that noble knight! he who the pouch / With the three beaks will bring!" He then twists his mouth and lolls his tongue like an ox. The narrator turns back from these spirits.

He finds Virgil already seated on Geryon's haunch. Virgil encourages him to be stout and bold for the steep descent, telling him to mount first so Virgil can be in the middle to protect him from the tail. The narrator is terrified, his nails turning blue, but shame makes him bold. He settles on Geryon's huge shoulders, wishing to say, "Look thou clasp me firm!" but words fail him. Virgil embraces him and commands Geryon to move with ample gyres and an easy descent, mindful of the unusual burden. Like a small vessel backing from land, the monster loosens. When at large, he turns his forked tail where his breast had been, steering like an eel, gathering air with retractile claws. The narrator feels immense dread, seeing only the beast and air, comparing it to Phaeton and Icarus. Geryon slowly sails, wheeling downward, unobserved by the narrator except for the wind from below. The narrator hears the cataract beneath them leap with a hideous crash, conceiving new terror at the steep plunge. He sees flames and hears wailings, crouching his limbs, then distinguishes how their downward course wound. Like a weary falcon, Geryon lands them at the base of the deep-furrowed rock, discharges his burden, and springs forward like an arrow.

**CANTO XVIII**
There is a place in hell's depths called Malebolge, dark-stained rock winding in a circle. In its midst yawns a spacious gulf. The remaining circle forms ten trenches (bolge) sunk in its hollow bottom, like fosses guarding a castle. Flinty paths advance from the rock's base, crossing the moles and dikes to the gulf. They are dislodged from Geryon's back. Virgil leads left, and the narrator follows.

On their right, the narrator sees new misery, pains, and executioners in the first chasm, swarming with naked sinners. They come meeting their faces from the middle point, with them beyond but with a larger stride. He compares it to Romans during Jubilee, devising means for crowds passing the bridge, some fronting the castle, some the mount. Horned demons with huge lashes unmercifully smite their backs, making them bound at the first stripe. None wait for the second or third. The narrator sees one he recognizes and cries out. Virgil pauses, allowing him to walk backward. The tormented spirit tries to hide his face, but the narrator exclaims, "Thou who dost cast thy eye upon the ground... Venedico art thou. But what brings thee / Into this bitter seas’ning?" The spirit replies he unwillingly answers, but the narrator's clear speech constrains him. He confesses he led fair Ghisola to do the Marquis's will. He says Bologna sends many such "barterers" here. A demon strikes him, crying, "Away! corrupter! here / Women are none for sale."

The narrator joins Virgil, and they come to a rock that issues from the bank. They ascend it, turning right, departing from those eternal barriers. Arrived where the arch lets pass the scourged souls, Virgil tells him to pause and observe other miserable faces. From the old bridge, they eye the pack coming from the other side, excoriated from the lash. Virgil, unquestioned, identifies a lofty shade as Jason, whose skill won the ram from Colchos. He beguiled Hypsipyle on Lemnos and left her pregnant. Medea's injuries are also avenged here. All who practiced like deceit bear him company. This suffices for the first vale.

They come to the next pier, where the path bestrides its shoulders to another arch. In the second chasm, they hear ghosts jibbering in low melancholy sounds, snorting with wide-stretched nostrils, and smiting themselves. A scurf from foul steam encrusts the banks. The depth is so hollow that the narrator cannot distinguish anything from below. They reach the summit of the rocky span, and thence the narrator sees a crowd immersed in ordure, appearing like "Draff of the human body." He marks one with his head so grimed it's hard to deem if he is clerk or layman. The spirit cries, "Why greedily thus bendest more on me, / Than on these other filthy ones, thy ken?" The narrator replies he has seen him with dry locks and recognizes him as Alessio of Lucca. The spirit beats his brain, saying his flatteries sunk him here. Virgil tells the narrator to stretch his face a little further to note the visage of a "besotted, sluttish courtezan" (Thais), who rends herself with defiled nails. Virgil says, "Thais is this, the harlot, whose false lip / Answer’d her doting paramour that ask’d, / ‘Thankest me much!’—‘Say rather wondrously,’ / And seeing this here satiate be our view."

**CANTO XIX**
The narrator pronounces woe on Simon Magus and his wretched followers, who prostitute God's things for gold and silver. This is the third chasm. They mount the following vault, where the rock impends directly over the center of the foss. The narrator praises Supreme Wisdom. He sees the livid stone full of apertures, all equal and circular, like baptismal fonts in Saint John's dome. He mentions breaking one to save a whelming infant, as a seal to undeceive doubters. From the mouth of every aperture emerge a sinner's feet and legs up to the calf, the rest hidden. The soles are burning, causing violent motion. Flames glide from heel to point.

The narrator asks Virgil who is in the fiercer flame. Virgil offers to carry him down where the slope bank falls least, so the spirit can tell his story. The narrator agrees, trusting Virgil. They come to the fourth pier, turn left, and descend to the depth, a narrow strait. Virgil does not set him down until he brings him to an orifice where a quivering limb expresses pain. The narrator addresses the "Sad spirit," asking him to utter his voice. He feels like a friar shriving a condemned murderer. The spirit shouts, "Ha! already standest there? / Already standest there, O Boniface! / By many a year the writing play’d me false. / So early dost thou surfeit with the wealth, / For which thou fearedst not in guile to take / The lovely lady, and then mangle her?"

The narrator is confused. Virgil admonishes him to tell the spirit he is not whom he believes. The narrator replies as enjoined. The spirit wrenches his feet and sighs, asking what the narrator requires. He identifies himself as one who wore the "mighty mantle" (Pope Nicholas III), the son of a she-bear, eager to advance his "whelps," for which he stored his wealth above and is here himself. Other simoniacs, his predecessors, are dragged beneath his head. He will fall lower when the one he mistook the narrator for arrives, but more time has passed since his soul kindled than is his doom to stand with fiery feet. He foretells that after him, one yet of "deeds more ugly" (Pope Clement V) will arrive from the west, a "shepherd without law," who will cover both his form and Nicholas's. This new Jason will be favored by France's monarch.

The narrator, perhaps presuming too far, replies, asking what treasures Christ demanded of St. Peter when he put the keys in his charge, noting he asked no more than "Follow me!" Neither Peter nor Matthias took gold or silver. He tells Nicholas his punishment is merited and to look to the ill-gotten coin that inspired his hardihood against Charles. If not for reverence of the keys, he would use severer speech. He blames avarice for casting the world in mourning, treading good, and raising bad men. He says the Evangelist was aware of such shepherds, seeing the harlot (corrupt church) with kings in filthy whoredom. He says they have made gold and silver their god, differing from idolaters only in worshipping a hundred gods instead of one. He laments, "Ah, Constantine! to how much ill gave birth, / Not thy conversion, but that plenteous dower, / Which the first wealthy Father gain’d from thee!"

As the narrator sings, the spirit, smitten by wrath or conscience, springs up violently, spinning on either sole. Virgil is pleased. He catches the narrator in his arms, lifts him to his bosom, and retraces his descent. He carries the narrator without weariness to the summit of the rock, their passage from the fourth to the fifth pier. He gently places his cherished burden on the rugged rock, a path not easy for a goat. Thence, another vale appears to the narrator's view.

**CANTO XX**
The narrator begins the twentieth strain, recording spirits whelmed in woe. He looks into the depth, moistened with tears, and beholds a tribe walking along the hollow vale, weeping in silence, like choirs chanting litanies. As he looks closer, each seems wondrously reversed at the neck-bone, so their countenances are averted from their reins, compelled to advance backward. The narrator notes he has never seen or believed such a thing. He asks the reader to consider how he could keep his visage dry, seeing their distorted form, tears streaming down their hinder parts. He leans against a rock and weeps. Virgil exclaims, "What, and art thou too witless as the rest? / Here pity most doth show herself alive, / When she is dead. What guilt exceedeth his, / Who with Heaven’s judgment in his passion strives?" He tells the narrator to raise his head and see Amphiaraus, before whose eyes earth gaped in Thebes, who fell to Minos. He makes his breast his shoulders, and now looks backward. He points out Tiresias, who changed sex. Aruns comes next, with his belly facing. His dwelling was a cavern in Luni's mountains.

The next spirit, whose loosened tresses overspread her bosom (Manto), settled in Virgil's native land. Virgil recounts that after her sire departed, she wandered, then fixed her seat in a waste territory amidst a fen, to shun human converse. Tribes gathered there, building a city on her dead bones, calling it Mantua. Virgil warns the narrator against other false origins. The narrator says he believes Virgil's words. He asks Virgil to instruct him about any other spirits of note.

Virgil points out a spirit whose beard sweeps over his shoulders (Eurypilus), the seer in Aulis who gave the sign to cut the cable when Greece was emptied of males. He refers to his own tragic strain. The next, slender of shape, was Michael Scot, practiced in magic. He points out Guido Bonatti and Asdente, who now repent not tending thread and cordwain. He then points to wretches who left their crafts to become diviners, working baneful witcheries with images and herbs. Virgil notes that Cain (the moon) now confines on either hemisphere, touching the wave beneath Seville's towers. Yesternight the moon was round and served the narrator well in the deep wood. Both move onward.

**CANTO XXI**
They pass from bridge to bridge, with other talk. They reach the summit, viewing another gap in Malebolge, with marvelous darkness. Like pitch boiling in the Venetians' arsenal, a glutinous thick mass boils here, liming the shore. The narrator sees only the surge. Virgil draws him back, exclaiming, "Mark! mark!" The narrator turns and sees a black devil running along the rock, with fierce cruelty in his look, buoyant wings, and nimble feet. His shoulder is charged with a sinner, held by the haunch, gripping the foot's sinew. The devil cries, "Ye of our bridge! keen-talon’d fiends! / Lo! one of Santa Zita’s elders! Him / Whelm ye beneath, while I return for more. / That land hath store of such. All men are there, / Except Bonturo, barterers: of ‘no’ / For lucre there an ‘aye’ is quickly made." He dashes the sinner down, turns, and speeds back. The sinner forthwith writhes to the surface. The dark demons, shrouded by the bridge, cry, "Here the hallow’d visage saves not: here / Is other swimming than in Serchio’s wave. / Wherefore if thou desire we rend thee not, / Take heed thou mount not o’er the pitch." They grapple him with more than a hundred hooks, shouting, "Cover’d thou must sport thee here; / So, if thou canst, in secret mayst thou filch." The narrator compares this to a cook thrusting flesh into a cauldron.

Virgil tells the narrator to bend low behind a craggy rock to screen himself, and not to fear any force or insult offered to Virgil, as he is well-advised. Virgil passes beyond the bridge's head. The demons rush forth, pointing their weapons at him. Virgil cries, "Be none of you outrageous: ere your time / Dare seize me, come forth from amongst you one, / Who having heard my words, decide he then / If he shall tear these limbs." They shout, "Go, Malacoda!" One advances, asking what this turn avails him. Virgil replies he comes by divine will and destiny to lead another through this wilderness. Malacoda's pride falls. He drops his instrument and tells the rest they have no power to strike him. Virgil tells the narrator to return safely. The narrator rises and moves with speed, fearing the fiends will break their compact. He compares it to infantry dreading a broken covenant at Caprona. He adheres to Virgil, observing their unkindly visage. They speak of touching him with hooks. Malacoda turns and tells Scarmiglione to stay. He adds that the rock affords no further footing, shattered at the sixth arch. But if they wish to proceed, they can go up by a cavern, where another rock will yield safe passage. He says that yesterday, five hours later than now, 1266 years and six had filled their course since the way was broken. He dispatches ten scouts, led by Barbariccia, to spy and safely lead them. The narrator expresses fear
value_gemini:
The generated summary is a highly detailed, Canto-by-Canto exposition of the *Inferno*, but it is critically incomplete.
