summary_llm:
The story is narrated by Nick Carraway, who moves from the Middle West to West Egg, Long Island, in the spring of 1922 to work in the bond business. He rents a small house situated between two enormous mansions, one of which belongs to the mysterious Jay Gatsby.

Nick visits his second cousin, Daisy Buchanan, and her wealthy husband, Tom Buchanan, at their elaborate Georgian Colonial mansion in fashionable East Egg. Tom is a physically imposing and arrogant man. Daisy is charming but cynical. At dinner, Nick meets Jordan Baker, a professional golfer. During the evening, the telephone rings, and Miss Baker reveals to Nick that Tom has a mistress in New York. Daisy is aware of this, showing a strained gaiety. Later, Daisy confides in Nick about her unhappiness and cynicism, expressing a wish for her young daughter to be a "beautiful little fool." As Nick leaves, he sees Gatsby standing alone on his lawn, stretching his arms towards a distant green light across the bay.

Some time later, Tom takes Nick to the "valley of ashes," a desolate industrial area, where they stop at a garage owned by George B. Wilson. Tom introduces Nick to Wilson's wife, Myrtle, who is Tom's mistress. Myrtle is a vital, sensuous woman in her mid-thirties. Tom arranges to meet Myrtle on the next train to New York. In the city, Tom, Myrtle, and Nick go to an apartment Tom keeps for Myrtle. Myrtle changes into an elaborate dress, and her personality becomes more affected. They are joined by Myrtle's sister, Catherine, and a couple named Mr. and Mrs. McKee. During the party, Catherine tells Nick that neither Tom nor Myrtle can stand their spouses and that Tom's wife, Daisy, is Catholic and doesn't believe in divorce, preventing Tom and Myrtle from marrying. Myrtle recounts her first meeting with Tom on a train. As the night progresses, fueled by alcohol, Myrtle repeatedly shouts Daisy's name, provoking Tom to violently break her nose with his open hand. Nick, disgusted, leaves with Mr. McKee.

Nick begins to attend Gatsby's lavish parties, which are frequent and open to many uninvited guests. He receives a formal invitation to one such party. At the party, Nick feels out of place until he finds Jordan Baker. They discuss rumors about Gatsby, including that he killed a man or was a German spy. Nick eventually meets Gatsby, who is younger than expected, with an "extraordinary gift for hope." Gatsby asks to speak to Jordan alone. Later, Jordan reveals to Nick that Gatsby told her he was an Oxford man, though she doubts it. The party ends chaotically with a car accident involving a drunk guest, "Owl Eyes," who was not driving the car.

Gatsby invites Nick to lunch. During the drive to the city in Gatsby's opulent car, Gatsby attempts to tell Nick about his past: being the son of wealthy Midwesterners (from San Francisco), educated at Oxford, and a decorated war hero. He shows Nick a medal from Montenegro and an old Oxford photograph as proof. Gatsby then reveals he has a "big request" and wants Nick to arrange a tea meeting with Daisy. Nick is annoyed that Gatsby is using Jordan as an intermediary. In the city, Gatsby introduces Nick to Meyer Wolfshiem, a Jewish man with cuff buttons made of human molars, who Gatsby reveals fixed the 1919 World's Series. Wolfshiem speaks highly of Gatsby, claiming to have "made him." Tom Buchanan briefly appears, and Gatsby quickly disappears, avoiding him.

Jordan then tells Nick the full story of Gatsby and Daisy. In 1917, Daisy Fay, a popular young woman in Louisville, was in love with Lieutenant Jay Gatsby. Jordan witnessed their intense connection. However, Gatsby went to war, and Daisy, under pressure, married the wealthy Tom Buchanan in 1919, receiving a $350,000 pearl necklace the day before the wedding. Daisy was drunk and almost called off the wedding after receiving a letter, but ultimately went through with it. A week after their honeymoon, Tom was involved in a car accident with a chambermaid, breaking her arm, which made the papers. Jordan explains that Gatsby bought his mansion in West Egg specifically to be across the bay from Daisy, hoping she would wander into one of his parties. He wants Nick to invite Daisy to tea so he can "come over" to Nick's house and see her. Nick agrees to arrange the meeting.

Nick calls Daisy and invites her to tea, specifically telling her not to bring Tom. On the day of the tea, which is rainy, Gatsby sends a gardener to cut Nick's grass and a greenhouse full of flowers to decorate Nick's house. Gatsby arrives, extremely nervous and pale. Daisy arrives, and the reunion is initially awkward and strained. Gatsby nearly knocks over a clock. After a moment of intense embarrassment, Gatsby and Daisy's joy at seeing each other becomes apparent. Gatsby invites Daisy and Nick to his mansion, where he shows Daisy his extravagant home and his extensive collection of expensive clothes. Daisy is overwhelmed and cries into a pile of his shirts, lamenting their beauty. Gatsby points out the green light at the end of Daisy's dock, revealing its profound significance to him as a symbol of his dream. Klipspringer, a "boarder" who lives at Gatsby's, is called upon to play the piano. Gatsby and Daisy become completely absorbed in each other, and Nick leaves them alone.

Gatsby stops throwing his large parties, dismissing his old servants and replacing them with people connected to Wolfshiem to prevent gossip, as Daisy now visits frequently in the afternoons. Daisy invites Nick and Jordan to lunch at her house. On a very hot day, Gatsby, Nick, Jordan, and Tom gather at the Buchanan's. Tom receives a phone call, which Jordan whispers is from Tom's mistress. Daisy openly kisses Gatsby when Tom leaves the room. Daisy's young daughter, Pammy, is brought in, and Gatsby appears surprised by her existence. Daisy tells Gatsby he looks "cool," and Tom, observing their interaction, realizes their affair. Tom insists they all go to town. Gatsby suggests they take his car, but Tom insists on driving Gatsby's car with Jordan and Nick, while Daisy rides with Gatsby in Tom's coupé.

On the way to the city, Tom, driving Gatsby's car, expresses his suspicions about Gatsby, questioning his "Oxford man" claim and revealing he's investigated Gatsby's business, accusing him of selling illegal alcohol through drugstores. They stop for gas at Wilson's garage. George Wilson is visibly sick and distraught, revealing he has discovered Myrtle's infidelity and plans to move West with her. Myrtle, from an upstairs window, sees Tom in Gatsby's yellow car and mistakenly believes Jordan Baker is Tom's wife, looking at her with "jealous terror."

At the Plaza Hotel in New York, a tense confrontation erupts. Tom aggressively questions Gatsby about his relationship with Daisy. Gatsby declares that Daisy never loved Tom and has always loved him. Daisy, under pressure, initially confirms she never loved Tom, but then admits she did love him "once," though she loves Gatsby now. Tom exposes Gatsby's illegal bootlegging operation, accusing him of being a "common swindler." Daisy is terrified and withdraws, begging to leave. Tom, asserting his dominance, tells Daisy to go home with Gatsby in Gatsby's car, stating that Gatsby's "presumptuous little flirtation is over." Nick, Jordan, and Tom drive back in Tom's coupé. Nick turns thirty that day.

As they drive back through the Valley of Ashes, they encounter a crowd at Wilson's garage. They discover that Myrtle Wilson has been hit and killed by a car. Michaelis, the coffee shop owner, recounts that Wilson had locked Myrtle upstairs, but she escaped, ran into the road, and was struck. Tom, seeing the yellow car, immediately tells Wilson that it wasn't his car and he just arrived from New York, implying Gatsby was driving. Later, Gatsby confesses to Nick that Daisy was driving the car, but he will take the blame. Gatsby waits outside Daisy's house all night, watching over her, but observes Tom and Daisy sitting together at the kitchen table, talking intimately and appearing to conspire.

The next morning, Nick goes to Gatsby's house. Gatsby is dejected. Nick urges him to go away, as the car will be traced, but Gatsby refuses to leave Daisy. Gatsby tells Nick the true story of his past: he was a penniless officer who fell in love with Daisy, making her believe he was from the same social strata and could care for her. He felt committed to her, pursuing her as a "grail." After the war, he was sent to Oxford, and Daisy, feeling the pressure of the world, married Tom. Gatsby returns to his house. The gardener asks to drain the pool as autumn approaches, but Gatsby asks him to wait, remarking he never used it all summer. Nick leaves for the city, but before he goes, he shouts to Gatsby that he is "worth the whole damn bunch put together."

Gatsby's father, Henry C. Gatz, arrives from Minnesota, having seen news of his son's death in the Chicago newspaper. He is grief-stricken but also immensely proud of "Jimmy's" success, showing Nick a photograph of Gatsby's mansion and a boyhood schedule of self-improvement. Nick tries to arrange a funeral. He calls Klipspringer, the "boarder," who refuses to attend, only calling to retrieve a pair of tennis shoes he left at Gatsby's. Nick also visits Meyer Wolfshiem, who also refuses to attend, stating his policy of not getting involved in such matters when a friend is killed. Nick receives a call from a man named Slagle, who mentions "Young Parke" being caught for bond fraud, implying Gatsby's illegal business connections. Nick informs him of Gatsby's death, and the call is abruptly disconnected.

The funeral is attended only by Nick, Mr. Gatz, the "owl-eyed" man from Gatsby's library, a few servants, and the postman. Daisy and Tom have left without leaving a forwarding address. Catherine, Myrtle's sister, lies at the inquest, denying any knowledge of Gatsby or Myrtle's affair to simplify the case, portraying Wilson as "deranged by grief."

Before leaving the East, Nick breaks off his relationship with Jordan Baker. She reveals she is engaged to another man and accuses Nick of being careless. Nick later encounters Tom Buchanan on Fifth Avenue. Tom admits he told Wilson that Gatsby owned the yellow car, justifying it by saying Gatsby "had it coming" and accusing Gatsby of running over Myrtle. Nick realizes that Tom and Daisy are "careless people" who "smashed up things and creatures and then retreated back into their money or their vast carelessness, or whatever it was that kept them together, and let other people clean up the mess they had made." Nick shakes Tom's hand, feeling as though he's talking to a child.

Nick decides to return to the Middle West, feeling that the East is haunted and distorted. He reflects on Gatsby's unwavering dream and his belief in the "green light," the future that always recedes. He concludes that people "beat on, boats against the current, borne back ceaselessly into the past."

summary_llm:
The plot of the provided text, "The Iliad," begins in the tenth year of the Trojan War.

**The Contention of Achilles and Agamemnon (Book I)**
The Greeks, having sacked neighboring towns, captured two beautiful women: Chryseïs, allotted to Agamemnon, and Briseïs, allotted to Achilles. Chryses, a priest of Apollo and father of Chryseïs, comes to the Greek camp to ransom his daughter. Agamemnon insolently refuses and dismisses him. Chryses prays to Apollo for vengeance, and Apollo inflicts a pestilence on the Greeks. Achilles calls a council, where the prophet Chalcas reveals that Agamemnon's refusal to return Chryseïs is the cause. Agamemnon is forced to return Chryseïs to appease Apollo but, in a fit of rage, seizes Briseïs from Achilles as compensation. Enraged and dishonored, Achilles withdraws himself and his Myrmidon forces from the war. He complains to his mother, Thetis, who supplicates Jupiter to grant victory to the Trojans, making the Greeks realize their mistake in offending her son. Jupiter grants her request, which incenses Juno. A heated debate ensues between Jupiter and Juno, eventually pacified by Vulcan.

**The Trial of the Army and Catalogue of Forces (Book II)**
To fulfill his promise to Thetis, Jupiter sends a deceitful dream to Agamemnon, urging him to lead the Greeks into battle, promising Troy's immediate fall. Agamemnon, though deluded, decides to test the army's morale by proposing a return to Greece. He calls a council of princes, where Nestor supports the idea of following the divine message. Agamemnon then addresses the assembled army, suggesting they abandon the siege. The troops, weary after nine years of war, unanimously agree and rush to prepare their ships for departure. Juno, observing this, sends Minerva to intervene. Minerva finds Ulysses and instructs him to rally the Greeks. Ulysses, wielding Agamemnon's sceptre, persuades the leaders and physically chastises the common soldiers, notably beating the insolent Thersites for publicly reviling Agamemnon and Achilles. Ulysses reminds the Greeks of Chalcas' prophecy about Troy's fall in the tenth year. Nestor then advises Agamemnon to organize the troops by nations. Agamemnon agrees, sacrifices a steer to Jupiter (who secretly rejects his prayer for Troy's fall), and the Greeks prepare for battle. The text then provides a detailed catalogue of the Greek forces and their leaders. Iris, sent by Jupiter, warns Priam of the approaching Greek army, disguised as Polites. Hector, the Trojan leader, rallies his own forces, and a detailed catalogue of the Trojan and auxiliary forces is given.

**The Duel of Menelaus and Paris (Book III)**
The armies advance. Paris, in the Trojan front, challenges any Greek to single combat. Menelaus, seeing Paris, eagerly accepts. Paris, however, retreats in fear. Hector upbraids Paris for his cowardice. Paris, stung by the rebuke, proposes a duel between himself and Menelaus to decide the war, with Helen and her treasures as the prize. Hector announces this to both armies. Menelaus accepts, demanding Priam swear the oath due to his sons' faithlessness. Priam, Agamemnon, and Ulysses swear the oaths, sacrificing lambs. Priam returns to Troy, unable to watch. Paris and Menelaus arm themselves. Paris throws his spear, which strikes Menelaus' shield but fails to pierce it. Menelaus throws his spear, piercing Paris' shield and corslet, grazing his flank. Menelaus then strikes Paris' helmet with his sword, which breaks. Menelaus seizes Paris by the helmet crest and begins to drag him. Venus intervenes, breaking the helmet strap and whisking Paris away in a cloud to his chamber in Troy. Menelaus searches for Paris in vain. Venus, disguised, then brings a reluctant Helen to Paris, who dismisses her reproaches and embraces her. Agamemnon declares Menelaus the victor and demands the return of Helen and the payment of a fine.

**The Breach of the Truce, and the First Battle (Book IV)**
The gods in council debate the war's continuation. Jupiter, after provoking Juno, allows Minerva to break the truce. Minerva, disguised as Laodocus, persuades Pandarus to shoot an arrow at Menelaus. Pandarus wounds Menelaus. Agamemnon and Menelaus lament the broken truce. The physician Machaon extracts the arrow and heals Menelaus. Agamemnon rallies the Greek troops, praising brave leaders like Idomeneus and the Ajaxes, and reproving those who hesitate. Nestor advises on battle formations. Diomed is reproved by Agamemnon but prepares for battle. The general battle begins fiercely. Antilochus kills Echepolus. Ajax (Telamonian) kills Simoisius. Ulysses kills Democoon. Hector rallies the Trojans, while Apollo encourages them and Minerva inspires the Greeks. Pyrus kills Diores, and Thoas kills Pyrus. The battle rages with many casualties on both sides.

**The Acts of Diomed (Book V)**
Minerva inspires Diomed, making him shine with divine light and granting him immense strength. He kills Phegeus and would have killed Idæus, but Vulcan saves Idæus. Minerva and Mars briefly withdraw from the battle. Diomed continues his rampage, killing many Trojans. Pandarus wounds Diomed with an arrow. Minerva cures Diomed, gives him the ability to distinguish gods from mortals, and instructs him to fight only Venus among the gods. Diomed returns to battle. Æneas, seeing Diomed's fury, persuades Pandarus to join him in his chariot to face Diomed. Diomed, after a warning from Sthenelus, refuses to retreat. Pandarus throws his spear, which hits Diomed's shield. Diomed, guided by Minerva, kills Pandarus with his spear. Æneas defends Pandarus' body. Diomed throws a massive stone, wounding Æneas in the hip. Venus saves her son Æneas, covering him with her veil. Diomed, recognizing Venus, pursues and wounds her hand. Venus, shrieking, drops Æneas. Apollo takes Æneas, covers him in a cloud, and carries him to Troy for healing. Diomed insults Venus. Iris helps Venus to Mars, who is sitting apart. Venus complains to Dione, her mother, about Diomed's attack. Dione comforts her, reminding her that gods also suffer from mortals. Juno and Pallas mock Venus. Jupiter tells Venus to stick to love. Apollo heals Æneas and creates a phantom of him to keep the Trojans fighting. Apollo urges Mars to rally the Trojans. Sarpedon upbraids Hector for his inaction. Hector, stung, rallies his troops, and Mars joins the Trojan side. Agamemnon rallies the Greeks. Diomed kills Deicoon. Æneas kills Orsilochus and Crethon. Menelaus and Antilochus retrieve their bodies. Menelaus kills Pylæmenes. Antilochus kills Mydon. Hector charges, and Diomed, seeing Mars with Hector, advises a tactical retreat. Hector kills Anchialus and Mnesthes. Ajax (Telamonian) kills Amphius. Tlepolemus challenges Sarpedon. They exchange boasts and spears; Sarpedon kills Tlepolemus, but Tlepolemus wounds Sarpedon. Ulysses kills several Lycians. Hector drives the Greeks back. Sarpedon is carried off wounded. Juno and Minerva descend in a chariot to aid the Greeks. Juno, in Stentor's voice, rallies the Greeks. Minerva reproaches Diomed for his hesitation and tells him to fight Mars. Minerva and Diomed mount the chariot. Minerva guides Diomed's spear, which wounds Mars in the groin. Mars bellows in pain and flees to Olympus. Jupiter rebukes Mars but has Pæon heal him. Juno and Pallas return to Olympus.

**The Episodes of Glaucus and Diomed, and of Hector and Andromache (Book VI)**
With the gods withdrawn, the Greeks gain the upper hand. Many Trojans are slain by various Greek heroes. Menelaus captures Adrastus and, urged by Agamemnon, kills him despite his plea for ransom. Helenus, Troy's chief augur, advises Hector to rally the troops and then return to Troy to instruct Hecuba and the Trojan matrons to offer a sacred mantle and twelve heifers to Minerva, praying for Diomed's removal from battle. Hector complies. Glaucus and Diomed meet between the armies. They discover their grandfathers were guest-friends and agree not to fight each other, exchanging armor (Glaucus foolishly exchanges his golden armor for Diomed's bronze). Hector arrives in Troy, where Hecuba offers him wine, but he refuses, instructing her to perform the sacrifice to Minerva. The matrons pray, but Minerva denies their request. Hector then goes to Paris' house, finds him polishing his armor, and reproaches him for his idleness. Paris accepts the rebuke and prepares to return to battle. Helen expresses her self-reproach and wishes she had died. Hector tells Paris he must leave to see his wife and son. Hector finds Andromache and their son Astyanax at the Scaean Gate. Andromache, weeping, pleads with Hector to stay within the city walls, fearing his death and the inevitable fate of their child and Troy. She recounts how Achilles killed her father, mother, and seven brothers. Hector explains his duty to fight for Troy and the shame of cowardice, acknowledging Troy's fated fall and Andromache's future as a captive. He embraces Astyanax, who is frightened by his helmet, and prays to Jupiter for his son's glory. Hector then comforts Andromache, telling her to return to her domestic duties. Hector and Paris, now armed, return to the battlefield.

**The Single Combat of Hector and Ajax (Book VII)**
Hector and Paris rejoin the battle, reinvigorating the Trojan forces. Paris kills Menestheus, Hector kills Eioneus, and Glaucus kills Iphinous. Minerva and Apollo meet and agree to halt the general battle for the day by inspiring Hector to challenge a Greek to single combat. Helenus conveys this divine message to Hector. Hector issues the challenge, proposing that the victor take the loser's spoils, but return the body for burial. The Greeks are initially silent with fear. Menelaus offers to fight but is restrained by Agamemnon, who reminds him of Hector's superior strength. Nestor shames the Greeks for their cowardice, recounting his own youthful valor. Nine Greek chiefs volunteer, and lots are cast. Ajax (Telamonian) wins the lot. Ajax and Hector exchange boasts and then spears. Hector's spear strikes Ajax's shield but does not pierce. Ajax's spear pierces Hector's shield and corslet, grazing his flank. They then throw stones, with Ajax knocking Hector down, though Apollo restores Hector's strength. As they draw swords, heralds intervene, declaring nightfall and stopping the combat. Hector proposes an exchange of gifts as a sign of respect, giving Ajax a sword, and receiving a belt in return. Both return to their armies. The Greeks feast, and Nestor advises building a fortification around their ships and camp. The Trojans hold a council. Antenor proposes returning Helen and her treasures, but Paris refuses to return Helen, though he offers her treasures and additional wealth. Priam suggests sending a herald to the Greeks with Paris's offer and requesting a truce for burning the dead. Idæus delivers the message. Diomed rejects the offer of treasures, insisting on Troy's complete defeat. Agamemnon agrees only to the truce for burial. Both armies burn their dead. The Greeks then build a wall, trench, and palisades around their camp. Neptune complains to Jupiter about this unhallowed construction. Jupiter promises to destroy the wall after Troy's fall. Both armies feast, but Jupiter sends thunder and lightning to dishearten the Trojans.

**The Second Battle, and the Distress of the Greeks (Book VIII)**
Jupiter convenes the gods, forbidding any intervention in the battle, threatening Tartarus for disobedience. Minerva obtains permission to offer advice, not direct aid. Jupiter goes to Mount Ida, where he weighs the fates of Greece and Troy; the Greek scale sinks. He sends thunder and lightning, terrifying the Greeks. Nestor's horse is wounded, and Hector nearly kills Nestor, but Diomed rescues him (Ulysses flees). Diomed and Nestor retreat, pursued by Hector. Jupiter sends lightning in front of Diomed's chariot, forcing them to flee. Hector boasts of his impending victory and plans to burn the Greek ships. Juno complains to Neptune, who refuses to defy Jupiter. Hector drives the Greeks back to their fortifications. Agamemnon, inspired by Juno, rallies the Greeks and prays to Jupiter. Jupiter sends an eagle omen, encouraging the Greeks. Diomed leads a renewed charge, killing Agelaus. Teucer, protected by Ajax's shield, shoots arrows, killing several Trojans. Agamemnon praises Teucer. Teucer shoots at Hector, misses, but kills Gorgythio (Priam's son) and Archeptolemus (Hector's charioteer). Hector, enraged, kills Teucer with a stone, breaking his bow. Ajax carries Teucer off. Jupiter again favors the Trojans, who push the Greeks back to their wall. Juno and Minerva prepare to intervene, but Jupiter sends Iris to warn them, threatening severe punishment. Juno and Minerva reluctantly return to Olympus. Jupiter returns to Olympus, rebukes the goddesses, and reveals his full plan: Hector will continue to conquer until he sets fire to the ships, then Achilles will return to battle after Patroclus' death, and Hector will die. Night falls, and the victorious Trojans camp on the plain, lighting many fires, to prevent the Greeks' escape. Hector orders them to keep watch and prepare for a final assault at dawn.

**The Embassy to Achilles (Book IX)**
The Greeks are gripped by fear. Agamemnon, weeping, proposes abandoning the siege. Diomed vehemently opposes this, vowing to fight on. Nestor praises Diomed and advises Agamemnon to strengthen the guards and send an embassy to appease Achilles. Agamemnon agrees, admitting his fault, and offers Achilles immense gifts: gold, tripods, horses, seven Lesbian captives (including Briseïs, whom he swears he never touched), twenty Trojan women after Troy's fall, and his daughter in marriage with seven cities. Nestor selects Phoenix, Ajax, and Ulysses as ambassadors. They find Achilles playing the lyre with Patroclus. Achilles welcomes them. Ulysses presents Agamemnon's offer and pleads with Achilles, reminding him of his father's advice to control his anger. Achilles fiercely rejects the offer, declaring his resentment for Agamemnon's dishonor. He states that he will return home to Phthia and advises the Greeks to do the same. He vows not to fight until Hector's flames threaten his own ships. Phoenix, Achilles' old tutor, recounts his own exile and how he raised Achilles, urging him to temper his rage, citing the example of Meleager. Achilles again rejects the plea. Ajax then reproaches Achilles for his stubborn pride. Achilles replies that Ajax's words are just, but his rage against Agamemnon is too deep. He reiterates his refusal to fight until his own ships are threatened. The ambassadors return to Agamemnon, reporting Achilles' refusal. Diomed encourages the Greeks to prepare for battle without Achilles.

**The Night-Adventure of Diomed and Ulysses (Book X)**
Agamemnon, sleepless with worry, consults Menelaus, then Nestor. Nestor advises sending a spy into the Trojan camp. Diomed volunteers, choosing Ulysses as his companion. They arm themselves. Minerva sends a heron as an omen. Hector, in the Trojan camp, also sends a spy, Dolon, promising him Achilles' horses and chariot as a reward. Diomed and Ulysses capture Dolon. Dolon, begging for his life, reveals the Trojan dispositions, including the recently arrived Thracian king Rhesus, with his magnificent white horses. Diomed kills Dolon. Ulysses dedicates Dolon's spoils to Minerva. They proceed to the Thracian camp, where Diomed kills Rhesus and twelve of his men in their sleep. Ulysses unties Rhesus' white horses and leads them away. Minerva appears to Diomed, urging him to return. They drive the horses back to the Greek camp, retrieving Dolon's spoils on the way. Nestor greets them, and they recount their successful mission. They stable the horses, dedicate Dolon's armor to Minerva, cleanse themselves, and feast.

**The Third Battle, and the Acts of Agamemnon (Book XI)**
Eris, sent by Jove, rouses the Greeks for battle. Agamemnon arms himself in splendid armor and leads the Greeks. Jove sends bloody rain. The Trojans, led by Hector, form their lines. The battle begins. Agamemnon leads a fierce charge, killing many Trojans, including two sons of Priam (Isus and Antiphus) and two sons of Antimachus (Pisander and Hippolochus), refusing ransom for the latter due to their father's past treachery. Agamemnon drives the Trojans back to the city walls. Jove sends Iris to Hector, commanding him to retreat while Agamemnon rages, but to return to battle once Agamemnon is wounded. Hector obeys. Coön wounds Agamemnon in the arm, but Agamemnon kills Coön. Agamemnon, in pain, withdraws from battle. Hector, seeing this, rallies the Trojans and charges, killing many Greeks. Ulysses and Diomed stand firm. Diomed kills Thymbraeus and his charioteer, and the sons of Merops. Paris wounds Diomed in the foot with an arrow. Diomed insults Paris and retreats to the ships. Ulysses is left alone, surrounded by Trojans. He fights bravely, killing several, but is wounded by Socus, whom he then kills. Ulysses calls for aid, and Menelaus and Ajax come to his rescue, driving off the Trojans and helping Ulysses to his chariot. Ajax kills Doryclus, Pandocus, and Lysander. Paris wounds Machaon with an arrow. Idomeneus tells Nestor to take Machaon to the ships for healing. Nestor takes Machaon. Cebriones, Hector's charioteer, points out Ajax's success. Hector charges Ajax. Jove fills Ajax with terror, causing him to retreat slowly. Eurypylus aids Ajax but is wounded by Paris. Patroclus, seeing Nestor with Machaon, asks Achilles who is wounded. Achilles sends Patroclus to Nestor's tent to inquire. Nestor recounts the many wounded Greek chiefs and urges Patroclus to persuade Achilles to fight, or at least to lead the Myrmidons in Achilles' armor. Patroclus, on his way back, meets the wounded Eurypylus and helps him to his tent, extracting the arrow and applying balm.

**The Battle at the Grecian Wall (Book XII)**
While Patroclus tends to Eurypylus, the battle continues at the Greek fortifications. The narrator explains that the Greek wall, built without divine offerings, is destined for destruction. Hector leads the Trojans against the wall. Polydamas advises Hector to dismount and attack the wall on foot, dividing the army into five battalions. Hector agrees, but Asius disobeys and drives his chariot to the gates, where he is repulsed by Polypoetes and Leonteus. An omen appears: an eagle carrying a bleeding serpent, which drops it among the Trojans. Polydamas interprets this as a sign that they will breach the wall but fail to take the ships. Hector rejects this advice, insisting on Jove's favor. Hector rallies his troops, and Jove sends a whirlwind to aid them. The Trojans attack the wall. Sarpedon, inspired by Jove, leads his Lycians against a section of the wall, encouraging Glaucus with a speech about their noble lineage. Menestheus calls for aid from the Ajaces and Teucer. Ajax (Telamonian) kills Epicles with a stone. Teucer wounds Glaucus with an arrow. Sarpedon, enraged, kills Alcmaon and then breaches the wall. Teucer and Ajax try to stop him, but Jove protects Sarpedon. Hector, with Jove's aid, heaves a massive stone and smashes through the main gates. Hector rushes through the breach, followed by the Trojans, driving the Greeks back to their ships.

**The Fourth Battle Continued, in Which Neptune Assists the Greeks: The Acts of Idomeneus (Book XIII)**
Jupiter, having given the Trojans an advantage, turns his attention away from the battle. Neptune, seeing the Greek distress, emerges from the sea, disguised as Calchas, and inspires the Ajaces and other Greek leaders with renewed courage. The Ajaces feel the divine inspiration and are eager to fight Hector. Neptune rallies the Greeks, shaming them for their retreat. The Greeks form a phalanx. Hector charges. Merion's spear breaks on Deiphobus' shield. Teucer kills Imbrius. Hector throws a spear at Teucer, missing him but killing Amphimachus (Neptune's grandson). Ajax (Telamonian) kills Imbrius and lops off his head. Neptune, enraged, further inspires the Greeks. He finds Idomeneus and encourages him. Idomeneus returns to battle, killing Othryoneus and Asius. Antilochus kills Asius' charioteer. Deiphobus throws a spear at Idomeneus, missing him but killing Hypsenor. Idomeneus then kills Alcathous. Idomeneus challenges Deiphobus, who seeks Æneas' help. Æneas, enraged, charges Idomeneus. Idomeneus calls for his allies. The battle rages around Alcathous' body. Idomeneus kills Oenomaus. Deiphobus throws a spear, missing Idomeneus but killing Ascalaphus (son of Mars). Merion wounds Deiphobus. Polites helps Deiphobus retreat. Æneas kills Aphareus. Antilochus kills Thoon. Merion kills Adamas. Helenus wounds Deipyrus. Menelaus wounds Helenus and kills Pisander. The Greeks gain ground on the left. Hector continues to fight the Ajaces in the center, but the Locrian archers harass the Trojans. Polydamas advises Hector to call a council to consider retreating into the city. Hector agrees, but first goes to rally Paris, whom he reproaches. Paris explains that Helenus and Deiphobus are wounded. Hector, appeased, returns to the center and confronts Ajax again.

**Juno Deceives Jupiter by the Girdle of Venus (Book XIV)**
Nestor, seeing the Greek wall breached and the Greeks fleeing, leaves Machaon and meets the wounded Agamemnon, Ulysses, and Diomed. Agamemnon proposes abandoning the siege. Ulysses vehemently opposes this. Diomed advises the wounded kings to return to the front to encourage the troops, staying out of harm's way. They follow this advice. Neptune, disguised, encourages Agamemnon and then shouts, inspiring the Greeks. Juno, seeing Jupiter on Ida favoring the Trojans, plans to deceive him. She adorns herself and obtains Venus' magic girdle of love and desire. She then persuades Sleep to put Jupiter to sleep, promising him Pasithaë, the youngest Grace, as his wife, and swearing an oath by Styx. Sleep and Juno fly to Ida. Juno seduces Jupiter, who falls asleep. Sleep then informs Neptune that Jupiter is asleep, urging him to aid the Greeks. Neptune rallies the Greeks. Hector throws his spear at Ajax, which is deflected. Ajax throws a huge stone at Hector, knocking him to the ground. Hector is carried off wounded by the Trojans. The Greeks, seeing Hector's retreat, press the attack, killing many Trojans. The Greeks gain ground, driving the Trojans back to the ships.

**The Fifth Battle at the Ships; and the Acts of Ajax (Book XV)**
Jupiter wakes on Ida, sees the Trojans fleeing, Hector wounded, and Neptune aiding the Greeks. He angrily confronts Juno, who swears she did not aid Neptune. Jupiter accepts her word and reveals his plan: Iris will command Neptune to withdraw, Apollo will re-inspire Hector, who will drive the Greeks to their ships. Patroclus will then fight in Achilles' armor, kill Sarpedon, but then be killed by Hector. Only then will Achilles return to battle, and Troy will fall. Juno flies to Olympus and sends Iris and Apollo to Jupiter on Ida. Jupiter commands Iris to tell Neptune to withdraw. Neptune, angry but obedient, retreats to the sea. Jupiter commands Apollo to revive Hector, give him the aegis, and lead the Trojans. Apollo descends, revives Hector, and leads the Trojans, terrifying the Greeks. The Greeks are driven back to their ships. Hector urges the Trojans to fire the ships. Apollo pushes down the Greek wall and fills the trench, creating a path. The Trojans rush to the ships. Nestor prays to Jove, who sends thunder as a sign. Patroclus, seeing the ships burning, rushes to Achilles. The battle rages at the ships. Hector kills Clytius, who was carrying a flaming brand. Hector throws his spear at Ajax, misses, but kills Lycophron. Ajax, enraged, calls to Teucer. Teucer shoots an arrow, killing Clytus. Teucer aims at Hector, but Jove breaks his bowstring. Ajax tells Teucer to use a spear. Hector boasts of Jove's favor. Ajax rallies the Greeks. The battle intensifies. Meges kills Dolops. Menelaus kills Melanippus. Antilochus kills Melanippus. Jove strengthens the Trojans. Hector kills Periphes. The Greeks retreat to the second line of ships. Nestor exhorts them. Minerva clears the mist. Ajax, wielding a huge mace, defends the ships. Hector seizes the stern of Protesilaus' ship, calling for fire. The battle becomes hand-to-hand on the ships. Ajax continues to fight, killing twelve Trojans who try to set the ships ablaze.

**The Sixth Battle, the Acts and Death of Patroclus (Book XVI)**
Patroclus, weeping, approaches Achilles, recounting the Greek distress and urging him to fight or allow him to lead the Myrmidons in Achilles' armor. Achilles agrees, but with strict orders: only drive the Trojans from the ships, do not pursue them to Troy, and do not engage Hector. Achilles wishes all others would perish so he and Patroclus could sack Troy alone. Ajax is overwhelmed, and Hector cuts off his spearhead. Ajax retreats, and Hector sets fire to Protesilaus' ship. Achilles, seeing the flames, tells Patroclus to arm. Patroclus dons Achilles' armor (except for his spear). Automedon harnesses Achilles' immortal horses. Achilles rallies his Myrmidons and pours a libation to Jove, praying for Patroclus' success and safe return (Jove grants the first, denies the second). Patroclus leads the Myrmidons, terrifying the Trojans, who mistake him for Achilles. Patroclus extinguishes the fires and drives the Trojans from the ships, pursuing them across the plain, killing many. Sarpedon challenges Patroclus. Jove debates saving Sarpedon but is persuaded by Juno to let fate take its course. Jove sends a shower of blood. Patroclus kills Thrasymed. Sarpedon's spear wounds Pedasus (Achilles' mortal horse). Patroclus kills Sarpedon. Glaucus, wounded, prays to Apollo, who heals him. Glaucus rallies the Trojans to retrieve Sarpedon's body. Hector joins the fight. Patroclus and Ajax rally the Greeks. The battle rages around Sarpedon's body. Jove covers the field in darkness. The Greeks eventually secure Sarpedon's body and Patroclus strips his armor. Jove sends Apollo to retrieve Sarpedon's body, cleanse it, and have Sleep and Death carry it to Lycia. Patroclus, disregarding Achilles' orders, pursues the Trojans to the walls of Troy, killing many. Thrice he attempts to scale the walls, but Apollo repulses him. Apollo, disguised, encourages Hector to fight Patroclus. Hector charges. Patroclus kills Cebriones (Hector's charioteer). Hector and Patroclus fight over the body. Jove shifts the sun, giving Greeks the advantage. Patroclus kills more Trojans. Apollo, in a cloud, strikes Patroclus from behind, disarming and stunning him. Euphorbus wounds Patroclus with a spear. Hector then kills Patroclus with a spear. Hector boasts over the dying Patroclus, who prophesies Hector's imminent death by Achilles' hand. Patroclus dies. Hector strips Achilles' armor from Patroclus' body and attempts to seize Achilles' horses, but Automedon drives them away.

**The Seventh Battle, for the Body of Patroclus (Book XVII)**
Menelaus guards Patroclus' dead body. Euphorbus challenges Menelaus and is killed. Apollo, disguised, urges Hector to fight Menelaus for Patroclus' body and Achilles' horses. Hector charges. Menelaus retreats, calling for Ajax. Ajax arrives, and Hector retreats, taking Achilles' armor from Patroclus' body. Ajax guards Patroclus' naked body, joined by Menelaus. Glaucus upbraids Hector for his cowardice and for abandoning Sarpedon's body, urging him to fight for Patroclus' body to exchange for Sarpedon's. Hector, enraged, puts on Achilles' armor. Jove grants Hector a moment of glory. Hector rallies the Trojans. Ajax rallies the Greeks. The battle rages around Patroclus' body. Jove covers the body in darkness. Ajax (Telamonian) drives back the Trojans. Hippothous, dragging Patroclus, is killed by Ajax. Hector's spear misses Ajax but kills Schedius. Phorcys is killed by Ajax. Apollo, disguised, encourages Æneas to fight. Æneas charges. The Greeks form a phalanx around Patroclus. The battle is lost in darkness around Patroclus' body, while the rest of the field is in daylight. Achilles, in his tent, is unaware. Menelaus and Merion struggle to carry the body. Ajax (Telamonian) sees Jove's intervention and suggests sending a messenger to Achilles. Ajax prays to Jove to dispel the darkness. Jove clears the air. Menelaus is sent to find Antilochus to deliver the news to Achilles. Antilochus is shocked and runs to Achilles. Menelaus returns to the battle, telling the Greeks Achilles is unarmed. Menelaus and Merion lift Patroclus' body. Ajax (Telamonian) and Ajax (Oïlean) cover their retreat. The Trojans pursue fiercely, but Ajax holds them off. The Greeks retreat slowly with the body.

**The Grief of Achilles, and New Armour Made Him by Vulcan (Book XVIII)**
Antilochus brings Achilles the news of Patroclus' death and the loss of his armor to Hector. Achilles is overcome with grief, covering himself in ashes, tearing his hair, and groveling. Thetis, his mother, hears his cries and comes with the Nereids. Achilles laments Patroclus' death and vows revenge on Hector, accepting his own fated death that will follow. Thetis promises to get him new armor from Vulcan. Meanwhile, the Greeks struggle to retrieve Patroclus' body. Juno sends Iris to Achilles, urging him to appear at the trench to scare the Trojans. Achilles, though unarmed, agrees. Minerva throws her aegis over him and creates a blazing golden cloud above his head. Achilles shouts from the trench, and his voice, amplified by Minerva, terrifies the Trojans. They retreat in panic, allowing the Greeks to retrieve Patroclus' body. Achilles weeps over the body. The sun sets. The Trojans hold a council. Polydamas advises retreating into the city, fearing Achilles. Hector rejects this, insisting they stay on the plain to press the attack at dawn. Pallas makes the Trojans approve Hector's bad advice. The Greeks mourn Patroclus all night. Achilles vows to sacrifice twelve Trojan captives on Patroclus' pyre and to give Hector's body to dogs. Thetis arrives at Vulcan's palace. Vulcan, recalling Thetis' past kindness, agrees to forge magnificent new armor for Achilles. He creates a wondrous shield depicting the cosmos, two cities (peace and war), agricultural scenes, and a herd attacked by lions. He also forges a cuirass, greaves, and a helmet. Thetis takes the blazing armor and flies back to Achilles.

**The Reconciliation of Achilles and Agamemnon (Book XIX)**
Thetis brings Achilles his new, divine armor. Achilles is filled with rage and fire. He expresses concern about Patroclus' body decaying, but Thetis reassures him, preserving the body with nectar and ambrosia. Achilles calls an assembly of Greeks and publicly renounces his wrath against Agamemnon, stating his grief for Patroclus outweighs all past grievances. He wishes Helen had died to prevent the war. The Greeks cheer. Agamemnon, without rising, blames Jove, Fate, and Ate for his past actions, recounting how Jove himself was once deceived. He reiterates his offer of gifts and swears publicly that he never touched Briseïs. Achilles accepts the gifts but insists on immediate battle. Ulysses advises the troops to eat and rest before fighting, and for Agamemnon to formally present the gifts and swear his oath. Agamemnon agrees. Achilles, still consumed by grief, refuses to eat until he has avenged Patroclus. Jove, pitying Achilles, sends Minerva to infuse ambrosia and nectar into his breast to sustain him. The Greek army arms. Achilles puts on his new armor, blazing like fire. He harnesses his immortal horses. Xanthus, one of the horses, miraculously speaks, prophesying Achilles' imminent death, not by their fault but by divine will. The Furies silence Xanthus. Achilles, undaunted, acknowledges his fate and rushes to battle.

**The Battle of the Gods, and the Acts of Achilles (Book XX)**
Greeks and Trojans prepare for battle. Jupiter calls a council of gods, permitting them to join either side, fearing Achilles might prematurely sack Troy. The gods descend to battle: Juno, Neptune, Minerva, Hermes, Vulcan for Greeks; Latona, Apollo, Mars, Xanthus, Diana for Trojans. The earth and Olympus shake. Apollo encourages Æneas to face Achilles, reminding him of his divine lineage. Æneas, though recalling a past defeat by Achilles, advances. Juno, seeing Æneas, calls a council of Greek-supporting gods. Neptune suggests they observe unless a god directly aids a mortal. Achilles and Æneas confront each other. Achilles reminds Æneas of his past flight. Æneas boasts his lineage and throws his spear, which strikes Achilles' shield. Achilles throws his spear, which passes through Æneas' shield. Achilles draws his sword. Neptune intervenes, casting a mist over Achilles, retrieving his spear, and transporting Æneas to the rear, warning him not to fight Achilles until Achilles' fated death. Achilles, realizing divine intervention, rallies the Greeks. Hector rallies the Trojans. Apollo warns Hector to avoid single combat with Achilles. Achilles charges, killing Iphytion, Demoleon, Hippodamas, and Polydore (Priam's youngest son). Hector, enraged by Polydore's death, charges Achilles. Hector throws his spear, but Pallas deflects it. Achilles charges, but Apollo shrouds Hector in a cloud, saving him. Achilles, furious, kills many more Trojans.

**The Battle in the River Scamander (Book XXI)**
The Trojans flee Achilles, some towards the town, others to the river Xanthus (Scamander). Achilles drives half into the river, killing many with his sword. He takes twelve Trojan youths alive as captives for Patroclus' sacrifice. He encounters Lycaon (Priam's son), whom he had previously captured and sold into slavery. Lycaon begs for his life, but Achilles, hardened by Patroclus' death, refuses mercy and kills him, throwing his body into the river. The river god Xanthus is enraged by the slaughter and choked with bodies. He tells Achilles to cease. Achilles agrees to stop killing in the river but vows to sack Troy and kill Hector. Xanthus swells his waters and attacks Achilles, sweeping him away. Achilles clings to an elm, which is uprooted, but he escapes to land. Xanthus pursues with huge waves. Achilles, exhausted, cries to Jove. Neptune and Pallas appear in human form, encouraging Achilles and promising victory over Hector. Achilles, re-energized, returns to the fight. Xanthus calls to Simois for aid, and the two river gods attack Achilles. Juno, fearing for Achilles, calls to Vulcan for aid. Vulcan unleashes his fires, burning the dead, drying the land, and boiling the river. Xanthus begs Juno to stop Vulcan, promising to desist from aiding Troy. Juno commands Vulcan to cease. The other gods resume fighting: Minerva strikes Mars down. Venus helps Mars away. Minerva strikes Venus. Neptune challenges Apollo, who refuses to fight. Diana upbraids Apollo. Juno seizes Diana, breaking her bow. Latona collects Diana's weapons. Hermes declines to fight Latona. Apollo enters Troy. Achilles continues his slaughter, driving the remaining Trojans towards the city gates. Priam orders the gates opened. Apollo, to save the Trojans, gives strength to Agenor, who faces Achilles. Agenor throws his spear, which strikes Achilles' greave. Achilles charges, but Apollo shrouds Agenor and transports him to safety. Apollo then takes Agenor's form and lures Achilles away from the city, allowing the remaining Trojans to retreat safely into Troy.

**The Death of Hector (Book XXII)**
The Trojans are safe within the walls, except for Hector, who remains outside the Scaean Gate, determined to face Achilles. Apollo, revealing himself, taunts Achilles for pursuing a god. Achilles, angered, rushes towards the city. Priam and Hecuba, from the walls, plead with Hector to come inside, fearing his death. Hector, fixed in his resolve, debates within himself, rejecting Polydamas' advice to retreat due to shame. He dismisses the thought of parleying. Achilles approaches, blazing like a star. Hector's resolve fails, and he flees. Achilles pursues Hector three times around the walls of Troy. The gods observe. Jupiter weighs their fates; Hector's scale sinks. Apollo abandons Hector. Minerva flies to Achilles. Minerva, disguised as Deiphobus (Hector's brother), appears beside Hector, urging him to make a stand. Hector, believing he has an ally, agrees to fight Achilles and proposes an oath to return the victor's body. Achilles furiously rejects any oaths, declaring his intent to kill Hector. Achilles throws his spear, but Hector dodges. Minerva retrieves the spear and returns it to Achilles, unseen by Hector. Hector, thinking he has wounded Achilles, throws his spear, which strikes Achilles' shield but is repelled. Hector calls for Deiphobus' spear, but he is not there. Hector realizes he has been deceived by a god and accepts his fate. Hector draws his sword and charges Achilles. Achilles, knowing the weak point in his own armor (worn by Hector), pierces Hector's neck. Hector falls, dying. Achilles boasts over him. Hector, with his dying breath, begs Achilles to return his body for burial. Achilles fiercely refuses, saying Hector's body will be eaten by dogs and birds. Hector, dying, prophesies Achilles' death at the Scaean Gate by Paris and Apollo. Hector dies. Achilles strips his armor. Other Greeks stab Hector's body. Achilles, in an act of vengeance, pierces Hector's ankles, ties them to his chariot, and drags Hector's body thrice around Patroclus' tomb, then back to his tent. Priam and Hecuba witness this from the walls and lament in despair. Andromache, unaware, hears the wailing, rushes to the walls, sees Hector's body being dragged, and faints. Revived, she laments Hector's death, the future of their son Astyanax, and the fall of Troy. She resolves to burn his clothes as a funeral offering.

**Funeral Games in Honour of Patroclus (Book XXIII)**
Achilles and the Myrmidons mourn Hector. Achilles orders them to drive their chariots thrice around Patroclus' body. Achilles lays his bloody hands on Patroclus' chest, promising Hector's body to dogs and twelve Trojan captives for the pyre. Hector's body is thrown before the bier. Achilles refuses to wash or eat until Patroclus is buried. He instructs Agamemnon to prepare wood for the pyre. The Greeks sleep. Achilles, by the shore, falls asleep. The ghost of Patroclus appears, asking for burial rites and for their bones to be mixed. Achilles tries to embrace the ghost, but it vanishes. Agamemnon sends Merion to Ida to cut wood. The wood is brought back. The Greek army processes around Patroclus' body. Achilles cuts a lock of his hair, vowed to Sperchius, and casts it into the sea. A large pyre is built. Patroclus' body is placed on it, along with fat, honey, oil, four horses, two dogs, and twelve Trojan captives sacrificed by Achilles. The pyre does not burn. Achilles prays to the Winds (Zephyr and Boreas). Iris, sent by Achilles, goes to the Winds, who then rush forth and ignite the pyre. All night the pyre burns, and Achilles mourns. At dawn, the flames subside. Achilles gathers Patroclus' bones, places them in a golden urn, and builds a tomb. Achilles then announces funeral games.
*   **Chariot Race:** Diomed wins 1st prize (a woman and a tripod-vase). Antilochus, by cunning, takes 2nd (a mare) from Menelaus. Menelaus complains, but Antilochus apologizes and yields the mare, receiving a talent of gold from Achilles. Merion gets 4th prize. Nestor receives the 5th prize (a double bowl) as an honorary gift.
*   **Boxing:** Epeüs defeats Euryalus.
*   **Wrestling:** Ajax (Telamonian) and Ulysses grapple to a tie. Achilles awards them equal prizes.
*   **Foot Race:** Ulysses wins 1st (a silver urn) after Pallas causes Ajax to slip. Ajax wins 2nd (an ox). Antilochus wins 3rd (half a talent of gold).
*   **Single Combat (Spear):** Diomed and Ajax (Telamonian) compete. The Greeks halt the fight, declaring them equal. Diomed is awarded a sword.
*   **Discus Throw:** Polypoetes wins a mass of iron.
*   **Archery:** Teucer cuts the cord of the target dove. Merion then shoots the dove as it flies. Merion wins the double-edged axes.
*   **Javelin Throw:** Achilles declares Agamemnon the best and awards him the spear without competition, giving Merion a charger.

**The Redemption of the Body of Hector (Book XXIV)**
Achilles, consumed by grief, cannot sleep. Each dawn, he drags Hector's body thrice around Patroclus' tomb. Apollo protects Hector's body from decay. The gods are moved by Hector's fate. Apollo complains about Achilles' cruelty. Juno defends Achilles. Jupiter commands Thetis to tell Achilles to return Hector's body for ransom, and Iris to tell Priam to go alone with gifts to Achilles, promising divine protection. Thetis delivers Jove's message to Achilles, who agrees. Iris delivers Jove's message to Priam. Hecuba pleads with Priam not to go, fearing Achilles. Priam prays to Jove, who sends an eagle as a favorable omen. Priam prepares rich gifts. He angrily drives away his remaining sons, lamenting their inferiority to Hector. Priam and his herald Idæus set off. Jove sends Hermes, disguised as a young Myrmidon, to guide and protect Priam. Hermes reassures Priam, reveals Hector's body is preserved, and guides them safely past the Greek guards to Achilles' tent. Hermes reveals his identity and departs. Priam enters Achilles' tent, embraces his knees, and kisses his hands, pleading for Hector's body by reminding Achilles of his own aged father, Peleus. Achilles is moved to tears, remembering his father and Patroclus. Both men weep. Achilles raises Priam, comforts him, and tells him to cease mourning, recounting the tale of Niobe. Achilles agrees to return Hector's body by Jove's command. He orders the handmaids to wash and anoint Hector's body away from Priam's sight. Achilles himself lifts Hector's body onto the funeral bed on the car, lamenting to Patroclus' shade. Achilles invites Priam to eat and rest. Priam requests twelve days for Hector's funeral rites. Achilles grants the truce. Priam and Idæus sleep in the porch. Hermes wakes Priam and Idæus, urging them to leave before the Greeks discover them. Hermes guides them safely out of the Greek camp. Aurora rises. Cassandra sees Priam's chariot with Hector's body and raises the alarm in Troy. The Trojans rush out, lamenting Hector. Priam orders them to take Hector to the palace. Hector's body is placed on a bed of state. Andromache, Hecuba, and Helen lead the lamentations, mourning Hector's death, the future of Astyanax, and the fall of Troy. Priam orders the Trojans to gather wood for the pyre. For nine days, they gather wood. On the tenth day, Hector's body is burned. At dawn, they quench the fire, collect his bones in a golden urn, and build a tomb. Guards watch during the rites. The Trojans return to Priam's court for a funeral feast. The mighty Hector's shade rests in peace.

For example, the original mentions "Achaean commanders become wounded," and the generated summary details *who* was wounded and *when* (e.g., Agamemnon, Diomed, Ulysses, Machaon, Eurypylus in Book XI). *   **Extra Details (in Generated, not found in Original):**

        *   **Divine Interventions and Motivations:** The generated summary extensively covers the gods' councils, their individual actions, disguises, and motivations (e.g., Juno's deception of Jupiter in Book XIV, the full "Battle of the Gods" in Books XX and XXI).
        *   **Battle Sequences:** The original mentions duels and Achaean losses; the generated summary provides minute-by-minute accounts of battles, including specific kills, wounds, tactical maneuvers, and the roles of various heroes (e.g., the "Acts of Diomed" in Book V, the detailed fight for Patroclus's body in Book XVII).
        *   **Subplots and Episodes:** Entire episodes like the "Trial of the Army and Catalogue of Forces" (Book II), the "Night-Adventure of Diomed and Ulysses" (Book X), and the detailed account of Hector and Andromache's farewell (Book VI) are present in the generated summary but only hinted at or entirely absent from the original's brevity.

summary_llm:
The narrative begins with a detailed description of the dilapidated Custom-House in Salem, Massachusetts, as observed by the narrator, who holds the position of Surveyor. He describes the building, its flag, and the general lack of commercial activity, contrasting it with its past bustling days. He then introduces his elderly colleagues, mostly aged sea-captains and Custom-House officers, who are largely inactive and prone to sleeping, but who are allowed to remain due to the Collector's (General Miller's) conservative nature. The narrator, a faithful Democrat, acknowledges his role in abbreviating the official breath of some of these venerable servants by representing them as needing rest, after which they soon died. He also describes a particularly robust and simple-minded Inspector, a "patriarch" of the Custom-House, who, despite his age, possessed immense physical vitality and a singular focus on the pleasures of eating, seemingly devoid of deeper intellect or moral sensibility. The narrator finds this Inspector to be the most fitting Custom-House officer he has known. He also sketches the Collector, General Miller, a former military hero now burdened by infirmities, whose mind, though dimmed, retains its strength and integrity. The narrator reflects on his own intellectual stagnation and loss of literary inspiration during his time in public office, feeling that his imaginative faculties have become "pointless and inefficacious."

One idle, rainy day, while sifting through old documents in an unfinished room of the Custom-House, the narrator discovers a small package wrapped in ancient yellow parchment. Inside, he finds a commission for one Jonathan Pue, a former Surveyor of his Majesty's Customs, and a piece of fine red cloth. This cloth, much worn and faded, is skillfully embroidered with gold thread and takes the shape of the capital letter "A." The narrator is strangely interested in it, and upon placing it on his breast, experiences a sensation of "burning heat," as if it were red-hot iron, causing him to shudder and drop it.

He then examines a small roll of dingy paper twisted around the letter. This manuscript, written by Surveyor Pue, provides a "reasonably complete explanation of the whole affair," detailing the life and experiences of a noteworthy personage named Hester Prynne, who lived between the early days of Massachusetts and the late seventeenth century. The narrator states that the main facts of the story he is about to tell are authenticated by this document, which, along with the scarlet letter itself, remains in his possession. He imagines the ghost of Surveyor Pue appearing to him, exhorting him to bring these "mouldy and moth-eaten lucubrations before the public" for profit, as the narrator's own office tenure is precarious.

Indeed, the narrator's reflections on the detrimental effect of public office on one's character prove prophetic. A "remarkable event of the third year of my Surveyorship" is the election of General Taylor to the Presidency, bringing in a hostile administration. The narrator, a Democrat, is summarily dismissed from his post, feeling like a "decapitated Surveyor." This involuntary withdrawal, however, frees his mind from its "wretched numbness" and allows him to return to his literary pursuits, using Surveyor Pue's manuscript as the foundation for his tale. He reflects that the Custom-House experience, though stifling, ultimately led him back to his true calling. He concludes the introduction by stating that his colleagues are now mere shadows, and he has disconnected from his old town, which will soon become a hazy memory.

The actual story, "THE SCARLET LETTER," begins with a throng of grim-faced Puritan men and women gathered before a weather-stained wooden prison in Boston. The prison, built early in the colony's history, appears old and forbidding. A wild rose-bush, growing by the prison door, is noted as a symbol of nature's pity.

On a summer morning, the crowd, particularly the women, eagerly awaits a penal infliction. They discuss the severity of the punishment for Hester Prynne, with some suggesting a brand of hot iron or even death. The town-beadle opens the prison door, leading forth Hester Prynne, a tall, elegant, and beautiful young woman, carrying a three-month-old infant. On her breast, Hester wears an elaborately embroidered scarlet letter "A" of fine red cloth with gold thread, a defiant display of her needlework. The beadle announces her sentence: to stand for three hours on the pillory platform in the market-place, and then to wear the scarlet letter for the remainder of her life. Hester endures the public gaze, her mind recalling memories of her past in Old England, including her parents and a pale, deformed scholar-like man (her husband). She clutches her child and touches the letter, confirming the painful reality of her shame.

Among the crowd, Hester spots a white man with an Indian companion. She recognizes the man, who is small, furrowed-faced, and slightly deformed, with one shoulder higher than the other. His face shows a fleeting expression of horror before he calms himself and gestures for Hester to remain silent. This man, Roger Chillingworth, asks a townsman about Hester's identity and crime. The townsman explains Hester is the wife of a learned English man who sent her to Boston two years prior, but has not been heard from since. Chillingworth reveals he is a wanderer, recently freed from Indian captivity, and asks about the baby's father. The townsman states Hester refuses to name him. Chillingworth, with a bitter smile, remarks that the father "will be known!"

Reverend John Wilson, an elder clergyman, urges Hester to confess the father's name from the balcony above the scaffold. Governor Bellingham supports this, placing the responsibility on the young Reverend Mr. Dimmesdale, Hester's pastor. Dimmesdale, pale and tremulous, implores Hester to reveal the name for her soul's peace, but she steadfastly refuses, stating the letter is "too deeply branded" and that her child must seek a heavenly father. A voice from the crowd, which Hester recognizes, also demands she speak. Dimmesdale, with a long respiration, murmurs, "She will not speak!" Mr. Wilson then delivers a long sermon on sin. Hester, in a state of insensibility, is led back to prison.

In prison, Hester is in a state of nervous excitement. Master Brackett, the jailer, brings in Roger Chillingworth, who introduces himself as a physician. Chillingworth, who had been held for ransom by Indians, first calms Hester's convulsing infant with an herbal draught. He then offers Hester a similar draught to calm her, assuring her it is not poison. Hester drinks it. Chillingworth reveals he is her husband, acknowledging his own "folly" in marrying her, an old, deformed scholar, to her youth and beauty. He declares he seeks no vengeance against Hester, but vows to find the man who wronged them both. He promises not to expose the father to public law or harm his life or fame, but to read the "letter on his heart" and make him "mine!" Hester is terrified by his words. Chillingworth then extracts a solemn oath from Hester that she will never reveal his identity as her husband. He leaves, smiling ominously, and Hester wonders if he is the "Black Man" who haunts the forest.

Upon her release from prison, Hester chooses to remain in Boston, settling in an isolated cottage on the peninsula. She supports herself and Pearl through her exquisite needlework, which is highly sought after for official garments and funerals, but never for a bride's veil. Her own dress is coarse and somber, adorned only by the scarlet letter, but Pearl is dressed in rich, fanciful garments, often crimson and gold, which seem to embody the scarlet letter itself. Hester gives her surplus earnings to charity, often receiving insults. She feels isolated and constantly tormented by the public gaze and the mockery of children. She develops a "new sense" from the scarlet letter, a sympathetic knowledge of hidden sin in others, which reveals hypocrisy in seemingly pious figures. Pearl, named as Hester's "treasure," is a wild, defiant, and uncontrollable child, reflecting her mother's impassioned state. Pearl's first conscious awareness was the scarlet letter, and she frequently fixes her gaze on it with a peculiar smile, causing Hester immense pain. Pearl often throws flowers at the letter on Hester's breast. When Hester asks Pearl who made her, Pearl replies she was "plucked by her mother off the bush of wild roses that grew by the prison-door," and later, touching the scarlet letter, declares she has no Heavenly Father. Hester is tormented by the townspeople's rumors that Pearl is a "demon offspring."

Hester visits Governor Bellingham's mansion to deliver embroidered gloves and, more importantly, to prevent the magistrates from taking Pearl away, as they believe Hester is an unfit mother. Pearl, dressed in crimson and gold, resembles the scarlet letter. Puritan children mock them, but Pearl fiercely chases them away. Inside the mansion, Pearl sees her reflection in a suit of armor, where the scarlet letter on Hester's breast appears exaggerated. Governor Bellingham and Mr. Wilson question Pearl's Christian upbringing. Pearl perversely states she was plucked from a rose bush. Hester fiercely defends her right to keep Pearl, appealing to Mr. Dimmesdale. Dimmesdale, pale and clutching his heart, argues that God gave Pearl to Hester as a blessing and a retribution, to keep her mother's soul alive. The Governor agrees to let Hester keep Pearl, provided she is catechized. Pearl, in a rare moment of tenderness, takes Dimmesdale's hand and allows him to kiss her brow, then laughs and capers away. Chillingworth remarks on Pearl's nature and asks if the father could be guessed. As Hester and Pearl leave, Mistress Hibbins, the Governor's sister and a reputed witch, invites Hester to a meeting with the "Black Man" in the forest. Hester refuses, but states that if Pearl had been taken, she would have gone and signed her name in the Black Man's book with her own blood.

Chillingworth, now living with Dimmesdale as his physician, is consumed by revenge. He relentlessly probes Dimmesdale's inner life, seeking his secret. Dimmesdale, though vaguely sensing an inimical presence, cannot identify his enemy and continues their familiar intercourse. Chillingworth gathers herbs from the graveyard, suggesting they grow from buried secrets. Dimmesdale, afflicted by his secret guilt, argues that only Divine mercy can reveal such secrets. Dimmesdale's health continues to decline, marked by paleness and a hand pressed to his heart, yet his powerful sermons earn him immense public reverence, which tortures him as he feels himself a "pollution and a lie." He practices self-scourging, fasting, and vigils, seeing visions of devils, angels, and his parents, and Hester and Pearl pointing at his breast. One night, Dimmesdale, in a somnambulistic state, goes to the scaffold where Hester stood. He shrieks aloud, but no one hears him as he intended. He sees Governor Bellingham and Mistress Hibbins, and then Mr. Wilson, passing by. He imagines the town finding him there. Pearl and Hester appear. Dimmesdale invites them onto the scaffold, and they form an "electric chain." Pearl asks if he will stand with them at "to-morrow noontide," but he refuses, promising to stand with them "At the great judgment day." A meteor flashes across the sky, which Dimmesdale, in his disordered state, interprets as a red "A." Pearl points to Chillingworth, who is watching them. Dimmesdale, terrified, asks Hester who the man is, expressing hatred. Hester remains silent due to her oath. Chillingworth approaches, feigning concern, and leads Dimmesdale home. The next day, Dimmesdale preaches a powerful sermon, but the sexton finds his glove on the scaffold, and the meteor is interpreted as an "A" for "Angel."

Hester, realizing the depth of Dimmesdale's suffering and Chillingworth's malevolent influence, feels a responsibility to act. Seven years have passed, and her public image has softened; the scarlet letter is now interpreted by many as "Able," recognizing her strength and helpfulness. She resolves to reveal Chillingworth's true identity to Dimmesdale. She finds Chillingworth gathering herbs by the sea. Hester sends Pearl to play, and Pearl, after playing with her reflection and making a "mermaid's garb" with a green "A" on her own breast, asks Hester what her scarlet letter means and why the minister keeps his hand over his heart. Hester, for the first time, lies, saying she wears it for the gold thread.

Hester confronts Chillingworth, observing his transformation into a fiend driven by revenge. He boasts of his torment of Dimmesdale, saying he has kept him alive to prolong his suffering. Chillingworth acknowledges that Hester herself is partly responsible for his transformation, and Hester, in turn, admits her hatred for him, recognizing her own wrong in marrying him. She declares her intention to reveal his secret to Dimmesdale. Chillingworth, in a moment of self-awareness, sees himself as a fiend and expresses pity for Hester, but maintains that their fate is sealed by a "dark necessity." He tells her to do as she will with Dimmesdale.

Hester meets Dimmesdale in the forest. They speak of their shared misery and his lack of peace. Dimmesdale confesses his agony and hypocrisy, longing for someone to know his true sinful nature. Hester reveals Chillingworth is her husband. Dimmesdale is horrified and initially blames Hester, but then forgives her, saying Chillingworth's revenge is "blacker than my sin." They sit together, finding solace in their shared secret. Hester urges Dimmesdale to escape with her and Pearl to the Old World, to begin a new life free from Chillingworth's torment and public shame. Dimmesdale, initially despairing, is invigorated by her plan and agrees, declaring, "Thou shalt not go alone!"

Hester, in a moment of joy and liberation, unclasps the scarlet letter and throws it away. Her beauty, youth, and warmth return, and the forest is flooded with sunshine. She calls Pearl to meet her father. Pearl, who has been playing with forest animals, approaches slowly. She sees her mother without the letter and refuses to cross the brook. Pearl points at Hester's breast, indicating the missing letter. Hester, saddened, retrieves the scarlet letter and fastens it back on. Her beauty and warmth vanish, and a gray shadow falls over her. Pearl then crosses the brook, embraces her mother, and kisses the scarlet letter. Pearl asks if Dimmesdale will walk hand-in-hand with them into town, and if he will always keep his hand over his heart. Hester tries to bring Pearl to Dimmesdale, but Pearl, influenced by her capricious nature, washes off Dimmesdale's kiss at the brook.

Dimmesdale, returning to town, feels an unaccustomed energy but also experiences strange, wicked impulses, barely restraining himself from blasphemous words or actions towards various townspeople. Mistress Hibbins encounters him, implying knowledge of his forest meeting with the "Black Man." Dimmesdale realizes his yielding to sin has unleashed a "brotherhood of bad ones" within him. He throws his unfinished Election Sermon into the fire and writes a new one with inspired fervor.

On Election Day, Hester and Pearl are in the market-place. Hester's face is calm, but Pearl is restless. The shipmaster, with whom Hester has arranged passage to Bristol for herself, Pearl, and Dimmesdale, informs Hester that Chillingworth has also booked passage on the same ship, intending to accompany "his friend, the gentleman you spoke of." Hester is horrified, realizing Chillingworth's relentless pursuit.

The procession begins, with military escort, magistrates, and then Dimmesdale, who walks with unaccustomed energy, delivering his powerful Election Sermon. Hester, watching him, feels his remoteness and doubts their shared future. Mistress Hibbins again speaks to Hester, hinting at Dimmesdale's secret connection to the "Black Man" and predicting his mark will be revealed. Pearl, playing in the market-place, receives a gold chain from the shipmaster, who also relays Chillingworth's message about their shared passage.

After the sermon, Dimmesdale, looking feeble and pale, totters towards the scaffold where Hester and Pearl stand. Governor Bellingham attempts to assist him, but Dimmesdale repels him. Dimmesdale calls Hester and Pearl to him. Chillingworth rushes forward, trying to stop him, whispering, "Madman, hold! what is your purpose?" Dimmesdale, asserting God's help, declares Chillingworth's power is broken. He calls Hester to support him onto the scaffold, Pearl holding his hand. Chillingworth follows, stating Dimmesdale could not have escaped him anywhere "save on this very scaffold!" Dimmesdale thanks God. He asks Hester if this public revelation is better than their forest dream, to which she replies she doesn't know, but that they may all die together. Dimmesdale, a dying man, addresses the multitude, confessing he is "the one sinner of the world!" He reveals that the scarlet letter on Hester's breast is but a shadow of what he bears on his own. With a convulsive motion, he tears open his ministerial band, revealing a mark on his breast (the text refrains from describing it). The crowd is horrified. Dimmesdale sinks down. Chillingworth kneels beside him, repeating, "Thou hast escaped me!" Dimmesdale tells Chillingworth, "May God forgive thee! Thou, too, hast deeply sinned!" He turns to Pearl, who kisses his lips, breaking a "spell," and developing her sympathies. Dimmesdale bids Hester farewell, expressing doubt about their reunion in an "everlasting and pure" state, but praising God's mercy in his afflictions, which included the burning torture on his breast, Chillingworth's torment, and his public death. He dies with the word "Farewell!"

After Dimmesdale's death, various accounts circulate about the mark on his breast. Most witnesses claim to have seen a scarlet letter "A" imprinted in his flesh, with theories ranging from self-infliction to Chillingworth's magic, or the gnawing of remorse. However, some deny any mark, believing Dimmesdale's death was a parable about human righteousness. The narrator, relying on Surveyor Pue's manuscript, confirms the former view and offers the moral: "Be true! Be true! Be true! Show freely to the world, if not your worst, yet some trait whereby the worst may be inferred!"

Roger Chillingworth, deprived of his object of revenge, rapidly withers away and dies within a year, having no further purpose in life. By his will, he bequeaths a considerable amount of property to little Pearl, making her a rich heiress. Not long after Chillingworth's death, Hester Prynne and Pearl disappear from Boston. Years later, Hester Prynne, still wearing the scarlet letter, returns to her old cottage. Pearl's fate is not explicitly stated, but indications (letters, luxuries in the cottage, a baby-garment Hester embroiders) suggest she is alive, married, happy, and mindful of her mother, living in another land. Hester chooses to resume her life in New England, of her own free will, and the scarlet letter, through her self-devoted years, ceases to be a stigma and becomes a symbol of awe and reverence. Women, burdened by their own sorrows, seek Hester's counsel. Hester comforts them and expresses her belief in a future "new truth" that will establish a surer relation between man and woman, though she no longer believes she is the destined prophetess. Many years later, Hester dies and is buried in the old burial-ground, near Dimmesdale's grave, but with a space between them. Their shared tombstone bears an engraved escutcheon with the motto: "ON A FIELD, SABLE, THE LETTER A, GULES."
